SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in paying tribute to the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), said that she had made history, and made history well. It is my honour this afternoon to nominate as her successor the person who has been at her right hand for the past 3 1/2 years, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay). Since his election in June 1979, the honourable member for Grayndler has made an outstanding contribution to this House. I will mention two areas of his service. First, I refer to his service on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, a committee on which the honourable member for Grayndler served between 1979 and 1986. He was that Committee's Deputy Chairman from 1981 to 1983 and its Chairman from 1983 to 1986. Secondly, the honourable member for Grayndler has served this House as its Chairman of Committees and Deputy Speaker from February 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The position of Speaker demands a thorough knowledge of the Standing Orders, the rules and procedures of this House. The honourable member for Grayndler has demonstrated a sound record in this area. On the occasions when he has occupied the chair as the Deputy Speaker and as Acting Speaker, he has applied the rules fairly and firmly. The position also requires sound administrative ability. Along with the President, the Speaker is responsible for the running of the Parliament. On the occasions on which he has acted in that role, the honourable member for Grayndler has performed those duties well.

The position of Speaker requires representational skills of a high order. On the many occasions on which the honourable member for Grayndler has represented the Parliament both here and overseas he has performed that role with diligence and distinction. The position of Speaker also requires a commitment to the committee system of this House. I have mentioned the service of the honourable member for Grayndler on the Expenditure Committee. Certainly, during his period as Chairman, the inquiries have been relevant to the needs of contemporary Australia. There have also been important inquiries. I mention just one-the inquiry into nursing homes. The report of the Committee was entitled In a Home or at Home. That inquiry led to the establishment of the Government's home and community care program. Under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Grayndler that Committee was truly an exercise in taking the Parliament to the people.

In 1987 the honourable member for Grayndler was also responsible for the development of the first comprehensive committee system for the House of Representatives. That committee system works well and it owes its success to the honourable member for Grayndler. He offers experience and a proven record in all of those four areas. In addition, he will bring to the position of Speaker a loyalty to and love of this institution. In his period of service not only has he developed an interest in a wide range of policy areas, but he also has a close interest in the way the institution works and its traditions. I recall that some years ago in a discussion the Leader of the House referred to the honourable member for Grayndler as the `parliamentarian's parliamentarian'. That truly sums up his commitment to this institution.

In many ways the position of Speaker is the loneliest job in this place. The Speaker frequently faces unique pressures and must face them alone. He must interpret the atmosphere of the House and move to a swift resolution of pressures. The honourable member for Grayndler will bring to this task a wealth of experience, a proven capacity for judgment, authority and determination, and a commitment to the Parliament. Above all, he will bring to the position great personal warmth. Both sides of the chamber have in the honourable member for Grayndler a person who will serve the House with distinction and in friendship and in the highest traditions established by his predecessors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that we nominate the honourable member for Curtin, Allan Rocher, for the position of Speaker. There are certain harsh realities about politics. As I commence these remarks, one reality is that the weight of numbers seems to be on the other side. If on this historic occasion, when the first woman Speaker retires, there could be equally some historic movement in the amorphous blob of the Caucus to consider the arguments, one would find that the argument in favour of Mr Rocher outweighs the argument in favour of the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay).

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Curtin was elected as a senator for Western Australia in 1977. He resigned in 1981 and was elected to the seat of Curtin at a by-election on 21 February 1981 and has retained the seat since then. He has been a significant contributor to debates in this House. He has served both Houses with distinction and has long experience in committees in the other place as well as here. He has served on the Senate Committee of Privileges, on legislative and general purpose committees, the House Standing Committee on Standing Orders and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and has been a most distinguished Deputy Chairman of Committees in this House since April 1983.

I recall that on a previous occasion, when the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) was nominating Mr Rocher, he referred back to the qualities that former Speaker Snedden defined as necessary for occupying the position of Speaker. A cursory examination of those qualities reveals to me that only Mr Rocher would qualify of all members in the Parliament. I will remind the House what they were: integrity, judgment, commonsense, firmness, patience, impartiality, tact, a sense of humour, self-confidence, presence of mind and, above all, firmness tempered with kindness. Nothing more befits the honourable member for Curtin and, with the greatest of respect to the honourable member for Grayndler, he runs second on every test. Allan Rocher unquestionably has all the prerequisites suggested by former Speaker Snedden and he would unquestionably make an excellent Speaker of the House.

I need hardly lecture honourable members on the nature and history of the Speaker in the Westminster system. However, the reality is that that impartiality that exudes from the Speaker's chair in the mother of parliaments, has not always been evident in this chamber, particularly under this Government. Honourable members would search in vain not merely for examples of the honourable member for Grayndler naming any miscreant on the other side but also for any Labor Speaker-save and except for Speaker Cope, and we know what happened to him as a consequence-seeking properly, within the Standing Orders of this Parliament, to deal with members from his own Party. Again, on that test, Mr Rocher comes with hands that are so clean that he named and had expelled the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). So one has a scalp on his belt and the other does not in terms of his own side.

We have not always received that degree of impartiality which the Parliament actually demands. Allan Rocher exudes that impartiality. It is with great pleasure, albeit with little confidence, that I move that he take the Chair of the House as Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great honour to second the nomination of the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) as Speaker of the Australian Parliament. The office of Speaker brings with it many onerous responsibilities, the most difficult being keeping dignity and order in this chamber, sometimes in periods of extreme tension between members and parties. Whilst serving with former Senator Reg Withers on a parliamentary committee a few years ago he offered me, as a relative newcomer, some pretty sound advice about this place. He said, `We're not here for a tea party, you know; it's a fight to the death to decide who will form the next government of Australia'. This `fight to the death', as Reg Withers called it, sometimes involves some pretty torrid exchanges in this House. The first qualification needed by any candidate for Speaker is the ability to keep order in this chamber with firm and fair decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last 3 1/2 years Leo McLeay, as Chairman of Committees and Deputy Speaker, has demonstrated that he has already developed the toughness required and earned the respect of both sides of this House which is needed to be Speaker. In particular, he has worked with the support of Speaker Joan Child to expand the role of the House of Representatives committee system which, in the long term, will significantly enhance the role of back bench members of this chamber and provide for a more rigorous examination of the Executive and the Public Service. As a member of the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on retirement incomes I also had the pleasure of serving with the honourable member for Grayndler in a series of meetings around the country. Again, he did a great job there.

Before Mr McLeay's election as Chairman of Committees, he was Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. His committee reports include Patronage, Power and the Muse, on funding for the arts, and his report In a Home or at Home on the provision of care for the elderly resulted in many changes, including the home and community care program and major reforms for elderly people. I understand that he was even responsible for lobbying for a bit more money from funding going to opera and ballet being redirected to our developing rock industry. That is something that I commend. As his taste in music indicates, Leo McLeay will be one of the youngest Speakers of this House; he is only 43 years of age.
Opposition members-How old?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members opposite just to listen as they will learn something. He was born in working class Marrickville. I am happy to note that both his parents are sitting in the gallery this afternoon, with his wife Janice and youngest son Martin. I am sure that they are very proud of their son, husband and father. Mr and Mrs McLeay must be proud that their son, the product of the local parish primary school, St Pius-and, like the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and myself, the product of the firm authority of the De La Salle brothers-can be nominated on this day in this chamber. I hope for those opposite that Mr McLeay does not use the same firmness and discipline that was applied by the De La Salle brothers. Leo McLeay, having left school at year 10, took his first job as a telegram boy at Marrickville Post Office. After becoming a telephone technician and working for Telecom Australia he worked very hard to be elected as the member for Grayndler, and he has served his constituents with distinction ever since. He will not forget those people in Marrickville and I am sure that he will discharge the office of Speaker and its responsibilities with dignity and distinction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding the nomination of Allan Charles Rocher. In doing so I must remark with some amazement at the comments made by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). I suggest that he chose his quote most inappropriately if he and the Government have any real commitment to the traditions of Westminster government. In nominating him for Speaker, to quote a partisan remark that reflects a commitment to partisan politics I think is quite amazing. I sincerely hope that, should Mr McLeay be successful in this ballot today, he will recant the remark that he is prepared to fight to the death to achieve the election of a particular party to government. What is fundamentally important in this place and in all parliaments throughout this country is that we do have independence and we do have a bipartisan approach from the Chair. Regrettably in recent times that has not always been obvious.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) spoke at some length about the qualities that Speaker Snedden identified as being important for a Speaker. He spoke of a person needing the highest integrity. When it comes to Allan Rocher's integrity there can be no question; when it comes to his judgment there can be no question at all. We saw an example of this in this place the other evening in his handling of a very sensitive incident involving a member of the Government, where he chose to take a very mature and independent approach to ensure that there was no embarrassment caused to the Parliament. That, of course, highlights his common sense which again is a fundamental quality required by a Speaker.

As I have said, these qualities are needed more than ever because of the events that have taken place in this Parliament in recent months and recent years. Never before, in the history of this Parliament, to my knowledge, have we had documents prepared which refer to the decline of Question Time, documents with a title which refers to the decline of Question Time in the Hawke era, blood sports and media events. What we need is a Speaker who will address the need to make this Parliament more relevant and more in tune with the community. Mr Rocher will of course address those problems. He would recognise the need to ensure not only that questions are asked in accordance with Standing Orders but also that answers are given in accordance with Standing Orders. Perhaps he would do something about the excesses of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in terms of the length and relevance of his answers. Perhaps he would even address the Treasurer's language. We on this side would not resile from his total commitment to enforcing the Standing Orders with impartiality to both sides of the chamber.

The quality required of a Speaker is to do something about the use of dorothy dixers which increasingly in this place are used as a substitute for parliamentary statements. I am sure that someone with the understanding of Standing Orders and the commitment to the Parliament and the Westminster system that Mr Rocher has would address that problem. There is an urgent need in the lead-up to the election to ensure that this Parliament remains relevant to the Australian community, that Question Time fulfils its appropriate role which is that it is an opportunity for information to be sought and information to be provided; for it no longer to be a media stunt for blood sports, or for the substitution of statements-this is provided for in other places in Standing Orders- or as an attempt to prevent the genuine seeking of information by the Opposition. It is important that Question Time become orderly, that all honourable members, including members of the back bench, have an opportunity to pose their questions. I have no hesitation in commending Mr Rocher's nomination to the House. I find him eminently qualified for the position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

SPEECH.PARA: The performance of Mr McLeay . . . is not good enough for Australia's Federal Parliament. It has been that way for more than two years.
However, there is no excuse for the occupant of the chair not knowing the standing and sessional orders of the House and the names of the electorates and which members represent them.
Mr McLeay has consistently shown that he does not have this knowledge.

—The Prime Minister asks who the Canberra Times is. That is a good one for the record. Let me go a bit further and look at the words of Derek Parker, a well known political scientist. He wrote in the Current Affairs Bulletin on April 1989 in the following terms:

This article is in relation to the Hawke Government's dealing with Question Time. It continues:

twenty minutes out of 45 minutes of Question Time-
five are from Mr Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order.
—The Leader of the House should sit down. He is half the cause of this. I am only reading a quote.

—My point of order is that under the Standing Orders relating to the debate on the election of a Speaker there is a requirement for the debate to be relevant. The points that have been raised here by the honourable member for O'Connor are points that are made in relation to the conduct of Question Time-when neither Mr McLeay nor Mr Rocher, the two candidates, has been in the chair. I would submit, therefore, that the detail in which the debate is taking place does not go to the character of either Mr McLeay or Mr Rocher and is irrelevant to the debate.
—This is a direct quote of how Question Time operates, Mr Browning, and the Standing Orders, of course--

SPEECH.PARA: The Clerk-I will rule on the point of order. It places me in a very difficult position, as the House would realise. I think the honourable member for O'Connor can continue in the vein that he has been following.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much. By their squeals would we know them. Continuing the quote of Mr Derek Parker in the Current Affairs Bulletin, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The standing orders, of course, do not stipulate the length of answers, so it is effectively left up to the Speaker. Very long answers, however, obviously limit opposition opportunities by reducing the overall number of questions. It is a tactic which can only work with the Speaker's approval and thus his or her agreement to a partisan strategy which involves a denial of what Question Time is for: the asking of questions.

That is the indictment from two independent commentators-the editor of the Canberra Times and Mr Derek Parker-of the person whom this Government has chosen to inflict on this Parliament. Members of the Government can always rely on my behaving myself when they do. That is the point that is most necessary to be known. They are the people who are abusing the Parliament and the Leader of the House takes most responsibility for that. If he gets off the Speaker's back, there may be a chance that that person will have the opportunity to do his duty in the way that Speaker Snedden once said it should be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the nomination of Leo McLeay for the position of Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawke

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Browning: I take vigorous exception, as I hope every member of the House would, to the interjection from over there, `Have you got an interpreter?'. It was an absolutely despicable interjection.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Clerk-I call the honourable member for Calwell.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) goes to the point I want to make about Leo McLeay, and that is, irrespective of factional differences, Leo McLeay has been one of the strongest supporters of multiculturalism in Australia. He has supported continuously all actions in favour of multiculturalism. His work for the various ethnic communities not only in his electorate but also throughout Australia has been outstanding. At a time when many people opposite could do well to recognise that Australia consists of people from all over the world-we are a multicultural society-Leo McLeay, in his work, has put forward a great deal and done a lot to promote that cause. In that regard he will be a Speaker who represents not merely the members of this House but also all Australians, because he is cognisant of the fact that Australia is a multicultural society and consists of people from many other places.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot from the Opposition about the abuse of Question Time. I am not aware of a claim in any democratic country, but it is made constantly by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), that it is not possible for a Minister, when answering a question, to compare the policies of the Opposition with those of the Government. If that determination were to be made, which it never has, it would be an abrogation of democracy. The continual interjections by the honourable member for O'Connor on that point are out of order. They have always been out of order. He is the one who has disrupted the Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Speaker having seated himself in the chair-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I very briefly, both personally and on behalf of this side of the House, offer my sincere congratulations to you on the achievement of this high office. I join with the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), who nominated you, in expressing the view that your family must be extraordinarily proud of you and your achievement. What you have done before coming to the chair has been adequately described on this side of the House. Your career commenced in the area of local government. In your time in this place you have displayed a considerable interest and involvement in and commitment to a wide range of areas of interest and importance to your constituents. I must, particularly from my own experience, refer to two areas. As has been said, you were co-chairman of my task force on retirement incomes. The work you did in that capacity played a significant part in the evolvement of the wide ranging policies the Government has been able to adopt with wide approbation in that area. I thank you for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, I have been in your electorate with you and have seen your absolute commitment to the interests of all sections of your community and your particular interest in trying to ensure that those who come to Australia from overseas to make this their new home should be made welcome in this country. We are all indebted to you for your particular interest in that area. You come to the Chair with great experience, great commitment, great integrity, and an appropriately wide range of interests which give you a feel for the real interests and aspirations of the Australian people. Therefore, both personally and on behalf of the Government, I congratulate you and wish you well.

I hope that you will also allow me the opportunity of briefly paying tribute to your predecessor, the honourable member for Henty, Joan Child. As has been said already in this House, and as I said in Caucus this morning, about the honourable member for Henty: she made history and she made it well. All our respect, regard and our affection go to the honourable member for Henty. We thank her for the job she has done over many years, and most particularly in her job as Speaker. We wish her every good thing for the future, in this place and beyond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker McLeay, of all the members in this chamber, there are only four of us who served under a previous Speaker McLeay-he, of course, of different weight and of different persuasion. But we congratulate you and we trust that by some form of osmosis or reconstruction you may take the view of the former Speaker McLeay, who was, in fact, one who practised his position with great impartiality, tact and wisdom. We, of course, commiserate with the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who came to the position nominated with great qualifications but few expectations today.

SPEECH.PARA: We wish you well. We believe, of course, in this great institution. The focal point in our democracy are the debates in the chambers of the House of Representatives and the Senate. You inherit a very great tradition which I trust you will execute in your duties according to the rules, Standing Orders, conventions and traditions. May I say personally to you that for all your feelings of satisfaction in being elected, as you survey the gallery it must give you that warm additional pleasure to see and sense that degree of satisfaction that your family must feel today. And on these occasions we join in congratulating you and say to them that we share, in a sense, the satisfaction of a family rejoicing in the elevation to the great post to which you have risen today. Party differences may divide us but your occupancy of that position, as I say, is an occupancy of very great tradition and convention, and we look to you to uphold it and wish you and your family all the best.

I also join with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in wishing the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) well. We cannot rewrite history. We have disagreed with a number of her rulings. But we hold her in the highest personal regard, and this is the first step in the process of two steps towards her retirement from this chamber. TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I add my congratulations to you on your election. Mr Speaker, not the least of your problems will be remedying the dearth and the conditions of employment of Hansard reporters. Whether that problem is the result of the amalgamation of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff into and subordinate to the Joint House Department is a matter for you. I will not refer to a delegation to France of which we were a part--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have.

—In any detail. I do not know whether ill health contributed to her decision-a decision I regret, incidentally-but if that is the case, I hope that that ill health will not linger for too long. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House from the bottom of my heart for the honour you have paid my family and me. I also thank you for the honour that you have bestowed on my electorate of Grayndler, which is one of the most ethnically diverse electorates in Australia. Only four members have represented the electorate of Grayndler since it was first created. I thank the House for allowing me to make my mark, along with Fred Daly, Frank Stewart and Tony Whitlam. I thank the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) for their remarks in support of my candidature. I am pleased to see that their eloquence swayed the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: I thank the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt), and the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) for their remarks. I assure the honourable member for Curtin that I value his friendship and I see no animosity in his decision to run for this office. In the 10 years that I have been a member of this Parliament I have made friends on both sides of the House. I hope I can continue to rely on those friends for advice.

When I was sitting in my office this morning thinking of what I should say today, I glanced at my desk calendar. The motto on the desk calendar read, `He that is overcautious will accomplish very little'. That, of course, reminded me of the old saying, `He who makes no mistakes learns little'. I hope that my friends on both sides will ensure that in the first month or two in which I hold this office I neither learn too much nor accomplish too much.

The honourable member for Dobell mentioned in his remarks that I had started my career as a telegram boy at the Marrickville Post Office. It is a long way from Marrickville Post Office to the high office of Speaker of the House of Representatives. But it does say to the people of my electorate that in Australia we still can be whatever we wish to be. For the people who live in my electorate, many who have come from countries around the globe where there is no such thing as parliamentary democracy, the fact that someone who has lived and grown up with them can reach this high office is of merit.

If the House will allow me, I would also like to make a few remarks about my good friend the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child). In joining with the Prime Minister and other speakers, I would like to say that the bond of friendship I have had with her over the last three years as her Deputy has made me feel a very lucky person. I particularly thank her for giving me the opportunity to hold this high office. The best way to sum up Joan Child is to read into the record the editorial in the Sydney Daily Telegraph this morning entitled `End of an era'. The editorial stated:

. . . much of the investment should contribute to future productive capacity . . .

The fact is that he and those opposite have got no comfort whatsoever from the Budget analysis that has been taking place since it was delivered, and the shadow Treasurer's prediction, as with most of his predictions, was lamentably off target.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at this question of Moody's. Perhaps the best thing I can go to first is the comment in the International Financing Review on 3 June 1989 when Moody's announced that it was going to have another look at Australia. This is what the International Financing Review had to say:

Last Friday, when Moody's announced that it was considering a downgrading of Australia's debt, it should have been aware that the reaction would be savage. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke led the counter-attack by saying: `Real questions need to be asked about Moody's professionalism and competence in taking this action'.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite laugh, but they will laugh on the other side of their faces when I quote further from this article, which leads off by quoting me and the Treasurer. It quotes me as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Real questions need to be asked about Moody's professionalism . . .
A month earlier, Australia's Treasurer, Paul Keating, had been equally scathing on the subject. Among his remarks were:
`They (investors) don't want to give their debt back because of the fact that we are now running a surplus on the Commonwealth account and we are not producing, we are killing debt.'
Another Keating comment was:
`The junk bond market has made monkeys out of the rating agencies as well they might.
The International Financing Review, having quoted the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, had this to say:

Even in 1974-75, there was not the slightest doubt that the United Kingdom would not be able to service its debt. The same is true of Australia in 1989, which is why we agree totally with the criticisms raised by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
There we have the International Financing Review looking at this political, incompetent exercise by Moody's. The International Financing Review quotes me and the Treasurer and then states:

. . . which is why we agree totally with the criticisms raised by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. If the ultimate credit risk in Australian government or government-guaranteed debt is zero-and we believe this to be true-the country's credit rating should be AAA.
Let me turn to what Salomon Brothers have had to say today about the Moody's exercise. Their article is entitled `Moody's downgrading unjustified'. Salomon Brothers state:

`It is not justified and there are two reasons why' Salomon's Sydney office Managing Director Trevor Rowe said. In the 1989-90 Federal Budget we have a large surplus and secondly, the retirement of public debt.
Rowe said:
Government debt is declining and the economy is in a stronger position than it was in 1986 when Moody's last downgraded Australia . . . This downgrading was not justified.
So there we have the comments of the International Financing Review and Salomon Brothers. Let us look at the local observation in today's Macquarie News:
National Australia Bank spokesman says he doesn't think the change will have any great effect.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —`Oh well, you see, it's a brother-in-law; now we'll attack everyone'. They have attacked the Commissioner of Taxation and the Australian Statistician. When honourable members opposite are landed with the truth, they should not abuse the messenger. They were talking earlier about abusing the messenger. The Westpac Banking Corporation had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Westpac's Bob Graham agrees and says he's disappointed by Moody's decision.

Just as honourable members opposite are on a furphy with the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia, so they are on a furphy with Moody's, and their most remarkable furphy is the pilots. Is that not a beauty? All I can say is that Lewis Carroll would sit back in awe as honourable members opposite entered into their Alice in Wonderland exercise about the pilots. What are we faced with in respect of the Opposition's attitude towards the pilots? It really is a bottler. What is the Opposition's policy in regard to industrial relations? Honourable members opposite criticise the situation. Let me give its historical context. Under this Government's industrial relations policy there has been virtually a 60 per cent reduction in the level of industrial disputes in this country.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Okay; let me give honourable members opposite the statistics. Average monthly working days lost per 1,000 employees-the standard textbook measure of the level of industrial disputation-were 241.7 during the working period April 1983 to April 1989, which is 58.5 per cent less than the average during January 1976 to March 1983. They are the statistics--
—When you were President of the ACTU.

—Such brilliant enterprise from the buffoon boy from Adelaide. He says that this occurred when I was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Let me deal with that matter as honourable members opposite have thrown that in. When I was President of the ACTU I wore the parliamentary corridors thin talking to and pleading with the conservative Government to adopt an industrial relations approach which I said was more appropriate than its confrontationism. I said, `The ACTU does not want to be in conflict. Let us sit down and talk and have a situation where the same rules apply to both sides'. I was rejected. Fortunately, as events turned out, I had the opportunity of putting to the Australian people in 1983 the proposition that there was a better way in industrial relations. I tried to get this in the period when honourable members opposite were in office. They would not listen. So I went to the people on 5 March 1983 and I said, `There is a better way'. The statistics show that there is a better way: a 60 per cent reduction in industrial disputation.

ANSWER.PARA: What is the Opposition's position? Confronted with the fact that under our policies there has been a 60 per cent reduction in industrial disputes, Opposition members put it to the Australian people that we should return to the chaos of 1981-82 when the centralised wage fixing system was abandoned and when what the nation had is what they are proposing now: let people go off and negotiate and get what they will in the market. They are now saying, `If the unions and the employers want to opt out of the system, our Liberal-National Party policy is that they opt out'. The Opposition's policy is for people to opt out and to go and negotiate. When the pilots do that, what is the Opposition's Alice in Wonderland answer? It is, `We will bring in legislation to impose more penalties inside the system'. The pilots have flown the coop. According to Opposition policy, what is the Opposition's answer? It is to impose more penalties inside the system from which they have fled. As I have said, Lewis Carroll would sit back in awe if he saw this Alice in Wonderland nonsense with which honourable members opposite go on.

Let us come to the facts of the dispute; they are quite simple. Let us understand the base from which the pilots are operating, and I quote from the publication of their previous President, Captain Fitzsimons. I give four brief quotes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!
—The Leader of the Opposition says, `Come on'.
—You asked three questions.
—The Leader of the Opposition asked three questions and he is going to get the full answer to his three questions.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is now being said that there were three questions. There was one question. That question was: In the light of these developments--
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is that the Prime Minister has taken 15 minutes now. We think that is long enough--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is quite clear why the Opposition does not like it, but it is going to continue to get it. We will now go to the pilots. As to the pilots dispute, I am saying what the position of the Government is and why the position of the Government is exactly what it is and will continue to be. The pilots have not moved from a position of intolerably bad conditions. This is what their previous President, Captain Fitzsimons, has had to say about their existing agreement:

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, . . . It is an excellent document that contains and maintains some of the best working conditions in the world of aviation.
Secondly, he then says to them:
You are the only bid system pilots in the world who have a block guarantee of pay.
He further says:
There is no other pilot group in the world that enjoys your overall standard of pay protection'.
His fourth point says that the total wage packet has been such that it is no longer accurate simply to compare gross salaries over a period.

From that position, described by one of their own leaders as the best in the world of aviation, what was the considered contribution of the pilots of Australia to the welfare of this country? They decided that they would make a claim for a 30 per cent increase. A 30 per cent increase on what? The average position of the pilots in question was an average salary of $80,000 a year for an average period of eight hours a week at the stick. They wanted a 30 per cent increase on that $80,000. Even members of the Opposition will not find it beyond their limited capacities to work out that a 30 per cent increase on $80,000 represents a claim for an increase equal to the average wage of Australian working men and women.

That is the position with which this Government was confronted. The pilots were not prepared to do what all the working men and women of Australia had done, and that is exercise restraint. That restraint had brought about a rate of employment growth in this country five times as fast as when the Opposition was in office and more than twice as fast as the rest of the world. That is what the workers of Australia had done. But that was not good enough for these people on $80,000 a year for eight hours a week at the stick. They wanted a 30 per cent increase, equal to the average wage of their fellow working men and women, and they said they were not going to operate within the system.

What did the Government do, and what are we continuing to to say? We are saying a very simple thing. We pleaded with them, saying, `Stay within the system and within that system your claims for an increase in salary can be properly processed, as have those of other Australian working men and women'. They said, `We will not work within the system'. We supported Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia and said, `If your employees will not accept the rights and obligations of the system and are going outside it, then in those circumstances we will support your use of whatever measures are necessary under the law to bring this to an end'.

Now that is the fact. This Government has not spent 6 1/2 years first of all to get this country out of the worst recession in 50 years, which was the Opposition's legacy, and then to create jobs five times faster than the Opposition did, to have the wages system and this economy blown apart by a group of people acting according to the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to a precedent on 12 February 1986, when the then Speaker ordered that the Prime Minister finish his answer. I put it to you that the Prime Minister has now been speaking for nigh on 20 minutes. He has obviously dealt with some of his subject matter on the question. He should now be asked to resume his seat.

—Order! The Prime Minister was asked by the Leader of the Opposition, who is usually given some latitude, a very wide-ranging question that related to at least three significant matters. The Prime Minister is answering the question.

—I know that the Opposition is in trouble. On each one of the points it has raised it is not the Government that is in trouble; on each one of them the Opposition has been shown to be at fault, to be wrong. On the third of these points let me conclude by saying in regard to the pilots dispute: what this country is witnessing at this time is the Opposition's industrial relations policy in action. We are witnessing the pilots acting according to the Opposition's industrial relations policy. We there have living proof of the drastic danger to this country of the industrial relations policy of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition was prepared, after seven years of office, to give this country its worst recession in 50 years. We are not prepared after 6 1/2 years to throw this country back to the economic chaos, the tyranny, that the Opposition imposed upon us. We will adhere to our policies in the budgetary area, in the wages policy area, in the monetary policy area, because it is our policies which have rescued this country. We will not allow the Opposition's policies to throw this country back into the depression, the recession and the tragedy which characterised the Opposition in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications and concerns the disruption to domestic air services resulting from the industrial action of Australian domestic airline pilots and their subsequent dismissal or resignation. Can the Minister advise the House what steps the Government has taken to provide a basic level of service and what prospects there are for this level of service to be increased?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member, I advise the House that a number of steps have been taken to try to ensure that we have a basic level of domestic air services in this country while the pilots continue to refuse to undertake their normal duties, indeed persist with the situation of a highly irresponsible claim and resignation from their employment. The measures taken, which will be generally known to members of the House and I mention them just briefly, are, firstly, that we have authorised all international airlines serving Australia to carry domestic passengers, freight and mail on domestic sectors of their existing international services. We have authorised foreign airlines to carry international interline traffic over Australia's domestic routes-that is, foreign travellers who are passengers of other airlines. That is a right previously enjoyed only by Qantas Airways Ltd. We have authorised foreign airlines to extend their international services to Australian cities they do not currently serve but are entitled to serve under the bilateral aviation agreements and to offer additional services over domestic routes that they are currently serving. We have authorised the Royal Australian Air Force to operate services for domestic passengers with planes crewed by RAAF personnel. We have also authorised the charter of an Ansett airfreight plane, a DC8 from the United States, on a fully crewed basis.
—Strikebreaking.

—That is an intriguing interjection from the honourable member for O'Connor, who says that the use of the RAAF is strikebreaking. I take it that means the Opposition is against it-or perhaps it is for it, I do not know. It is curious that the Opposition sees it as strikebreaking.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.
—What I might say, Mr Speaker--
—The Minister will not respond to the interjections.

—It just puts the Opposition in line with the pilots. The results of the measures taken by the Government have been significant. They cannot, of course, provide the same level of service as we would have if we had normal domestic services in this country, but we have been able to maintain a reasonably basic level of service. There are 17 foreign carriers operating over domestic routes in Australia and 16 of them agreed to carry Australian domestic passengers. One of those who originally agreed, United Airlines, has now seen fit to withdraw that agreement as a result of the unwillingness of its pilots to be involved in carrying domestic passengers. In the first five days of the new arrangements the foreign internationals have carried 9,100 domestic and interline passengers. Qantas has carried 8,200 passengers of a type it would not normally carry. These are mostly interline passengers who would normally have travelled with the domestic airlines. There have been some few hundred more domestic passengers despite the fact that Qantas pilots said that they did not want to carry them, only those they regarded as having compassionate grounds. The RAAF has operated nine aircraft. It has one 707, four Hercules and four Hawker Siddeley 748s. It is serving areas not well served by the internationals-that is, Perth, Adelaide, Darwin, Alice Springs and Tasmania, in the main, and also north Queensland. It has carried over 7,000 passengers in the last four days. Altogether, the special arrangements have enabled 24,300 passengers to be carried around Australia in the last five days.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to further developments and the prospects for further increases in capacity, I advise the honourable member and the House that we can expect another RAAF 707 to come into service later this week following its release from the Kangaroo 89 exercise. Negotiations are continuing between the domestic and international carriers to use international planes for domestic services during their down time in Australia. Quite a few international flights spend a lot of time in Australia before returning overseas. The use of those planes for domestic services during that down time in Australia would seem likely to be very productive of additional services in the near future. We also expect that that would be particularly important for services to Perth. Despite the loss of United we believe that capacity should be considerably increased over the present approximate 15 per cent of normal capacity.

Finally, I advise the House that airlines have received a substantial number of applications following recent advertising at the end of last week both within Australia and overseas for pilots to apply for positions following the resignation of all of the airlines' pilots. Ansett has received around 200 applications, as has Australian Airlines. East-West has received about half of that number-that is, about 100. There are real prospects that domestic airlines could be operating their own aircraft in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Was an agreement worked out between Qantas Airways Ltd and its pilots for a 15 per cent wage rise in return for productivity improvements for crews for the new Boeing 747-400 series aircraft? Did the Prime Minister or one of his Ministers revoke that agreement last Friday, 25 August? Does the Prime Minister now expect industrial action by Qantas pilots as a result of this action of his Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the discussions that we had with the two domestic airlines last week a question was raised by both about difficulties that were created for them by what they understood to be the action of Qantas, which had not abided by two agreements. Those two agreements were to the effect that should Qantas be approached to be involved in any discussions which concerned salary upgrading due to new configurations of aircraft it would not come to any agreement without prior discussion with the two domestic airlines. The two domestic airlines were naturally enough concerned that they should be faced with a situation where Qantas would have done that. In light of suggestions that this had happened inquiries were made of Qantas by the relevant Ministers to ascertain whether this was the case. It was put to Qantas that we would not tolerate that situation if that had happened, if it broke agreements with the airlines as to what should be done in terms of pilot remuneration in those circumstances. It was made quite clear that that would not be accepted. As I understand it, Qantas, in the light of that approach that was made to it and the position of the Government being made quite clear to it, gave an undertaking that no such agreement had been finalised and that--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Finalised!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am telling the Opposition what was put. This is one of the quaint things about members of the Opposition. They come in here and make assertions that that is not so. I am directly answering the question asked of me by saying that in respect of that position we have been given an undertaking by Qantas that that arrangement would not be proceeded with and would not be finalised now unless the agreements that it had beforehand were adhered to and that that would be done within the system. It was certainly the case that there had been some discussion where it looked as though there could have been a move towards an agreement of the type involved in the honourable member's question.
—Ah!
—There is an `Ah!' from the Leader of the Opposition. Because it is in line with the Opposition's policy, it presumably--
—Your system.

—Let me refute the interjection of the Leader of the Opposition. It is not our system. I am saying that the system that was being followed by Qantas and the pilots was not our system. We said to them that it is not our system and we will not tolerate it. The point I am making is that it was very much the system of the Opposition. By asking that question members of the Opposition are presumably again saying that they support that approach. I have news for them. If they think that the people of Australia are going to tolerate this sort of deal system where already privileged people are going to do deals which are not in line with existing agreements-this is what was being done by Qantas-then I have news for them. This Government is not going to cop that system. We have made it clear to Qantas that we will not cop it just as we made it clear to the domestic pilots that we will not cop it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition is asking whether the Qantas pilots will go out as a result of our intervention. I do not know whether he wants that or not, but let me say that if the Qantas pilots were to adopt the same approach as the domestic pilots--
Mr N.A. Brown interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Menzies.

—If they believed they could operate outside the system, then this Government would adopt the same approach as it has with regard to the domestic pilots. As I said in answer to a previous question, the Government and the community of Australia are witnessing a situation with regard to domestic pilots where a privileged group of people are saying to the rest of their fellow Australian workers, `Wage restraint operating according to the guidelines is good enough for you poor mugs but not for us'. All I am saying is that we will not accept it in regard to domestic pilots. I have no reason to believe on the evidence available to us that, with regard to Qantas, as a result of the intervention by the Ministers in the terms I have put there will not now be an acceptance of our system-that is, the centralised system with guidelines that are laid down in the interests not only of the parties immediately involved but of the country as a whole. That is what this Government is committed to. The tragedy is that those opposite are not.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories aware of concerns which have been widely voiced, including by the Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission, about the likely effects on the inbound tourism industry of the current pilots dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt in anybody's mind that tourism, which became our major export earner only a matter of weeks ago-it is worth $6.5 billion in export earnings-has been seriously damaged by the irresponsible actions of the pilots.
—And the Government.

—We will deal with that. The reality is that as a result of the pilots' industrial action the tourism industry in Australia is involved in a massive exercise of damage control. In any one day in Australia there are some 6,000 overseas visitors. One can imagine the sorts of things that they will say about Australia as a tourist destination when they get back home, as they are faced with the problems of not getting onto aeroplanes and not being able to get to their destinations. The Australian Tourist Commission, as part of that damage control exercise, has cooperated fully with major overseas operators, particularly in Germany and Japan. Under their consumer protection laws those operators, having sold packages for their tourists, can be confronted with significant legal actions in their own countries if there is a failure to deliver on the contracts that they have undertaken. That is a problem.

ANSWER.PARA: There can be no doubt, in my mind, that many sections of the tourist industry are in a difficult position. Many major hotels are starting to lay people off. The operator of a major resort told me today that he was thinking of closing and many segments of the industry are looking at the issuing of legal proceedings against not merely the Australian Federation of Air Pilots but individual pilots. Such a situation would be disastrous not merely for the pilots in the long term but for the Australian economy and this very important aspect of Australia's economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your policy. You want to close down Qantas.
—The honourable gentleman says that that is our policy. Our policy is to try to get this issue resolved as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Peacock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say this to the Leader of the Opposition: Having regard to the Opposition's track record, I would have thought that it would have been more than fulsome in its condemnation of the pilots' actions, but all we have is a lot of shifting and filling. Let us look at what has occurred and the detail of the Opposition's policy. The Opposition's policy which has been advocated involves, first of all, conducting a secret ballot before anyone can go on strike. The pilots had their secret ballot and decided to go on strike. Secondly, its policy, which it has announced widely-it has made no secret of it-is that employers and workers should go outside the Industrial Relations Commission; they should abandon it and get into collective agreements. That is exactly what the pilots said they wanted. The Opposition can bleat, but let us deal with its policy and how it has been applied to the letter by the pilots.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Peacock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject I will warn him, and then I may name him. The Minister will answer the question. Members on my left will cease interjecting, so that we can hear the Minister answer. However, the Minister might bring his answer to a close.

—I will bring my answer to a close. Any analysis of the detail of the coalition's policy involves employers and workers going outside the Commission. That is what has occurred. That encourages the enforcement of common law proceedings to back up voluntary agreements. That is what is just starting to occur. The fact also remains that, if one considers the benefits that pilots obtained within the system, one sees that, whilst average weekly earnings for the rest of the work force increased by some 38 per cent in recent years, pilots' weekly earnings increased by some 48 per cent.
—How did yours go?

—It is time that the Leader of the Opposition took a proper stand on this. Did his shadow Minister for industrial relations, when confronted with these facts, come out and say, `We believe in collective bargaining and this is the result of collective bargaining'? No. Senator Chaney said-and I agree with him-that the pilots ought to get back into the Commission; that the way to resolve the dispute was by sensible negotiations within the Commission. He proposes a private member's Bill to strengthen the Commission's powers in respect of a group that has walked out of the Commission. It is not there any more, so whatever Senator Chaney proposes cannot be enforced. The pilots have operated on coalition policy right to the hilt. Opposition members see the effects of that in action and do not like what they see, so they come into this place like a bunch of wimps. They are not prepared to condemn them or to stand up to them. They are carrying out the Opposition's policy and the people of Australia and the tourism industry are suffering because of it.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House whether, in discussions with airline operators, there has been any offer, deal, proposal or request that the Federal Government provide any form of financial assistance to any or all airlines during the pilots dispute? If so, can the Prime Minister advise the House of the likely timing, terms and conditions of such financial assistance, and the anticipated cost to taxpayers?

—I have been asked this question on at least three occasions in the media. I have given the answer as it is and I will now give the answer as it is, and that is that, when we met with representatives of Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia in my office at an early stage of this dispute, the representatives of Australian and of Ansett raised the issue of possible compensation from the Government. The response that I gave to them, and it remains the position, was this: I said that we would not give any commitment in that regard. I said that this was an early stage of the dispute and it should proceed. I said that if the dispute went on for a considerable period it would be open to them to raise the issue with us and we would then give consideration to it. That is the beginning and the end of this matter as far as the Government is concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIVE SHEEP EXPORTS TO SAUDI ARABIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the House as to what steps have been taken in recent years to support Australia's reputation as a reliable supplier of healthy live sheep? Further, what steps have been taken to ensure the well-being of animals consigned to this trade with the Middle East?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bendigo for his question and the close interest he takes in the sheep industry. Recently I informed the House of the Saudi Arabian rejection of some, but not all, recent shipments of live sheep from Australia, allegedly on the basis of disease. I should mention now that the Australian Government and Australian industry have yet to see any scientific evidence for these allegations. Honourable members will perhaps be aware that all five shipments diverted from Saudi Arabian ports have now been unloaded. The Kuwaiti authorities, for example, have declared the sheep to be free of bluetongue, sheep pox and brucella melitensis-after taking proper diagnostic tests.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, some people with axes to grind in Australia have attempted to attribute the shipment rejections to the general health status of Australian sheep and the quality of Australian veterinary surgeons and the professional judgment of people they once worked with. That is not only mischievous, it is wrong and ignores many efforts which have been made to enhance the welfare of live sheep for export. Sheep are checked by veterinarians before leaving Australia and are accompanied by trained stockmen who oversee the animals' welfare during the voyage. Although veterinarians do not accompany every shipment, they do so periodically. Indeed, a Western Australian department veterinarian was on board one of the vessels rejected by the Saudi authorities.

There has been a steady and marked reduction in animal mortality levels from the unacceptable levels of the 1970s, and an improvement in the animals' general turn-out condition. This has been achieved through, for example, new codes of practice for export feed lots; revised standards for export feed pellets; and detailed specifications for sheep carriers, particularly in regard to pen sizes, ventilation, watering and feeding systems. Export control powers are used to ensure that professional animal welfare standards are maintained. This is not to say that there is any reason for complacency. We should continue to see the monitoring of animal welfare as a matter of priority. To this end I recently established the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare. The Government is continuing high level efforts to resolve the trade dispute with Saudi Arabia. I will advise the House of further developments as they come to hand.

Is it a fact that Arrow Air has an appalling safety record in North America, including a crash which cost 256 lives, and that this airline is one of the foreign charter operators which has been allowed into Australia under fast tracked Civil Aviation Authority approval over the weekend. Is the Prime Minister concerned that allowing Arrow Air to operate in Australia could jeopardise safety? Will he give a guarantee that any charter aircraft that may come in for passenger movements will get more than the cursory approval that happened in this particular case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the details in regard to Arrow Air.
—The Minister says it is ridiculous.

—I would have thought that if the honourable member had wanted to maximise his opportunity of getting precise information it would have been more sensible to address the question to the Minister for Transport and Communications but I am not going to attempt to dodge the question; I will answer it. I am simply saying that if the honourable member wants more details I suggest he talk to the Minister, but let me make these points. Firstly, I am not aware of any details in regard to Arrow Air that the honourable member has referred to. But let me make the point that the attitude of the Minister, and quite properly, has been this: these operators who are in question will not be allowed to operate in Australia in regard to providing additional services unless they meet the requirements, the high standards and specifications of the Australian civil aviation industry.

ANSWER.PARA: We have the independent authorities whose statutory responsibility it is to discharge those obligations and to see that people who operate in Australia will meet those requirements. The Minister is operating on that basis, that is, that there will be the requirement that before these people are allowed to come into Australia they will meet the requirements of our relevant authorities. I am not quite sure, Mr Speaker, what the thrust behind the honourable gentlemen's question is. Is it that the Opposition really wants to stymie--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is safety.

—The honourable member says it is safety. What we are facing is this: the Opposition is questioning in one way or another whether in fact the Government should not give in to the pilots. The Opposition has a totally ambivalent position. There are those in the Opposition who have voiced support for the outrageous claims of the pilots, then they think about it and they say that perhaps they had better not have a position that is entirely in support of the pilots, perhaps they had better say, as the Leader of the Opposition has said-who is making his little theatrical performance now--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Peacock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the Leader of the Opposition.

—What the Leader of the Opposition has said is that he totally supports every action that has been taken by the Government. Here we have the Leader of the Opposition who has gone to the media and said that he supports the action of the Government in regard to the provision of Royal Australian Air Force services and in regard to attempting to obtain ancillary services from overseas. That is what the Leader of the Opposition has said. Now the honourable member gets up and asks this question which apparently is based upon some assumption that we have not done the right thing, that the Opposition does not agree with it. TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I table the Government's policy information paper on the national HIV/acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) strategy, and I seek leave of the House to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on my first opportunity to address you as such let me congratulate you on your elevation to the chair. You will recall that just over nine months ago, on 22 November 1988, I tabled in this House the Government's policy discussion paper on AIDS-`A Time to Care, A Time to Act: Towards a Strategy for all Australians'. That paper presented the wide range of issues and options relevant to the HIV epidemic in Australia as a basis for consultation, discussion and formulation of a national strategy on AIDS for the foresee- able future.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time, I promised the members of this Parliament and the people of Australia that I would return in the 1988-90 Budget context with a clear, broad strategy to guide Australia in the management of AIDS during the next stages of the epidemic, and that the Australian community would have the opportunity to participate in the consultative process. That process is now complete.

The policy information paper I present to the House sets out the policies and programs which the Federal Government believes are appropriate to deal with the HIV epidemic into the 1990s, as well as the parameters for funding, administering, coordinating and monitoring this nation's AIDS programs and activities.

The national strategy encompasses complex medical, scientific, economic, legal and moral issues within a framework in which the protection of public health is always paramount. It has absorbed and reflects a wide range of views obtained from the comprehensive consultation process which involved State governments and authorities, the research community, those who care for people with HIV, the private sector, unions, people with HIV, the Australian National Council on AIDS, the Inter-Governmental Committee on AIDS, the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations, the Parliamentary Liaison Group on AIDS, concerned individuals and representatives of many community groups.

The cornerstone of this process was the six working panels which I established early this year to provide a forum for public consultation. Those six panels-which included honourable members and senators from both sides of this Parliament-held 38 meetings and met with 1,800 people, from Perth to Cairns, Hobart to Darwin, and Alice Springs to Palm Island, and visited prisons in Sydney, Brisbane and Perth. The reports of the panels were published in May this year and, along with the written submissions received, provided a broad-based and bipartisan input to development of the national strategy. The policy information paper, or White Paper, is not just a document for governments, people with AIDS or those who care for people with AIDS. The policies and programs it contains are designed to reach and influence all members of the community because AIDS has the potential to touch the lives of all Australians.

When I addressed the House on this issue last November, I informed honourable members that 1,100 cases of AIDS had been reported in Australia, that 538 of those people had died, and that the number of cases continued to mount inexorably. On every day since then, at least one new cases of AIDS has been reported in this country. On almost every day since then, another life has been lost to the disease. As at 9 August 1989 there have been 1,414 cases of AIDS reported in Australia, and 733 of those people have died, nine out of 10 of those Australians who have contracted the disease are or were under 50 years old.

It is a fact that homosexual or bisexual transmission continues to account for the overwhelming number of AIDS cases in this country, some 88 per cent. However, incidence of the disease among intravenous drug users-including homosexual and bisexual IVDUs-has risen to 3.8 per cent and heterosexual transmission has increased to 1.6 per cent of reported cases. While prevalence of AIDS remains relatively low among these latter groups, the experiences of overseas countries, particularly the United States of America, demonstrates starkly the incipient threat which AIDS continues to pose to the wider community.

In the United States HIV infection is as high as 30 per cent among intravenous drug users and is steadily increasing in the heterosexual community. In New York City, for example, AIDS is the biggest killer of women under 30 years, and, tragically, one in 60 babies there is born with the virus. Surveys carried out in Sydney show increasing rates of infection among intravenous drug users from less that one per cent to more than 10 per cent over the past two years. With the estimated number of drug users in Australia ranging from 90,000 to 130,000, the potential for spread through the drug conduit among the heterosexual community is therefore inescapably significant. Denial of that threat now would be unwise and ultimately, of course, tragic.

Unfortunately, there are some people in positions of influence within our community, including one or two honourable members in this House, who are encouraging others to deny the potential for transmission of the virus among the heterosexual population. Rather than viewing the currently low prevalence of heterosexual infection as an opportunity to modify behaviour pre-emptively, and thus turn good fortune to good management, they choose to use data showing what was happening yesterday as an excuse to deny that a real problem exists today. It is these same people who seek to undermine Australia's consensual approach to AIDS with allegations that our policies to deal with this epidemic have been hijacked by the homosexual lobby.

It was just such divisive and damaging tactics which Jonathan Mann, Director of the World Health Organisation's Global Program on AIDS, spoke about at the fifth international conference on AIDS in Montreal in June. Dr Mann warned of a third epidemic of social, cultural, economic and political reaction and response to AIDS `in which the twisted bring forward their twisted ideas of massive cover-ups and AIDS conspiracies (and this) threatens increasingly to overshadow and overwhelm the epidemics of HIV and AIDS themselves'. Dr Mann said that this third epidemic could be as important to our future as the virus itself if complacency, fatalism and marginalisation were allowed to reduce the commitment to or change the course of efforts to protect public health.

The people who peddle these myths about gay conspiracies, who prefer the potentially fatal consequences of denial to the guarded optimism of realism, either fail or refuse to understand that the cooperation of the victims of AIDS-in this country to date, predominantly homosexuals-is essential to our ability to stem the epidemic. We have never disguised the rationale of our efforts to give people with AIDS confidence in the health services of this country through our emphasis on privacy, on confidentiality, on anti-discrimination, on adequate counselling, on opposition to compulsory testing, on endeavours to reduce the stigmatisation associated with AIDS.

None of these steps has been taken primarily on the grounds of civil liberties or human rights, but on the grounds of public health. The Government has always believed that the protection of public health, rather than the preservation of individual rights, must be the overriding concern in developing and implementing AIDS policies and that public health and individual rights march hand in hand on the AIDS issue because the health and well-being of the many is dependent upon the cooperation of the few.

In the words of Admiral J. D. Watkins, in his landmark report on AIDS in the United States, effective anti-discrimination protection is, paradoxically, the sine qua non of an effective HIV containment policy. That paradox is possibly the most important thing we have learned about management of the AIDS epidemic since I first addressed this House on AIDS more than four years ago. We have also learned that history holds no simple truths for combating AIDS, and that there are no easy answers to this awesome health crisis. AIDS is a new disease presenting an unique set of public health problems.

But there have been a few shafts of light. We have learned that the overwhelming number of Australians have the strength to resist the temptation to succumb to draconian measures offered as facile and ineffectual `quick-fixes' to the disease, and that we possess the individual and collective commonsense and will to take the superficially less attractive, but potentially much more effective, decisions demanded by AIDS.

Australia has become internationally acclaimed for its approach to the dilemmas posed by the disease, leading most countries in the world in terms of the development of logical, cohesive and effective containment policies. Our efforts have won praise because, from the beginning of the epidemic, we have taken a cooperative approach involving the development of an unprecedented partnership and level of trust between all levels of government, all political parties and the affected community groups.

The production of this policy information paper is another first for Australia among the developed nations of the world. The twin goals of Australia's unique national HIV/AIDS strategy are to eliminate transmission of the virus and to minimise the personal and social impact of HIV. The strategy is ambitious and purposely so. The Government believes it would be derelict in its responsibility for the public health of Australians if it were to be anything less.
The goal is supported by 10 principles developed to guide the formulation of policy and appropriate program responses. They are:
1. Transmission of HIV is preventable through changes in individual behaviour; education and prevention programs are necessary to bring about such changes.
2. Each person must accept responsibility for preventing themselves becoming infected through sexual intercourse or the sharing of needles and for preventing further transmission of the virus.
3. The community as a whole has the right to appropriate protection against infection.
4. The law should complement and assist education and other public health measures.
5. Public health objectives will be most effectively realised if the cooperation of people with HIV infection and those most at risk is maintained.

6. Specific informed consent should be obtained before any test is performed to diagnose a person's HIV infection status. The result should remain confidential, and appropriate pre- and post-test counselling should be provided.

7. People infected with HIV retain the right to participate in the community without discrimination, and have the same right to comprehensive and appropriate health care, income support and community services as other members of the community.

8. Professional care givers have a duty to care for infected individuals; government, employers and unions have a responsibility to provide working conditions and training programs which minimise the risk of occupational transmission.
9. Research into the epidemic is essential to the management of the epidemic.
10. General principles of public health, service provision and the legal system should be applied to the HIV epidemic; special measures or services require justification.

The national strategy has six key elements: education, prevention, treatment care and counselling, access and participation, research, and international cooperation. It is based on our best scientific knowledge at this time. Obviously, if a cure or vaccine were to become available, if radically new treatments became available, or if the nature or progression of the virus were to alter significantly, the Government would need to reconsider the appropriateness of the national strategy. The education and prevention strategies outlined in the paper are premised on the basis that transmission of the AIDS virus is preventable and that education remains the most effective means of prevention.

I would like to place on record, specifically for the benefit of people who continue to argue that our AIDS education efforts to date have been improperly targeted to the whole community rather than to people most at risk, that the Government spends approximately $7.50 per head on AIDS education within high risk groups, compared with approximately 27c per head on AIDS education on the whole community. It will be heartening too for all honourable members to note that major studies indicate a decline in the rate of infection in homosexual men, and significant behavioural change among homosexual and bisexual men. While none of this is reason for complacency, nor any indication that the epidemic has peaked or stabilised, it does indicate that the emphasis we have placed on, and hopes we place in, preventive education are not misplaced. The education strategy outlined in our policy information paper has three broad target groups:
people whose activities place them at greater risk of infection than the general community and those infected;
carers of people with HIV, including professional care givers; and
the general community.

A new national media campaign will have two specific purposes. First, it will address the specific educational needs of groups which might not be reached through community based programs, including bisexual men, non-dependent drug users and people of non-English speaking background. Second, the campaign will be used to raise the level of awareness in the general community about modes of transmission and to allay fears and prejudice about the virus. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will be consulted in developing a public education campaign directed against AIDS-related prejudice and discrimination. The new Commonwealth AIDS prevention and education, or CAPE, program will replace the former existing community education grants to provide funds to community based organisations which develop nationally relevant prevention and education programs for priority groups identified in the national strategy. Funds will be earmarked for grants to organisations developing programs for Aboriginal and Islander communities, people of non-English speaking background, and services for tertiary students. The States will receive substantially increased education and prevention funds to meet State priorities. Some of this matched funding will be tied.
