For example, the Government is asking the States to ensure that education programs are introduced for prisoners and prison staff, people in residential institutions and their families and carers, homeless young people and children in detention centres, police, and other State employees.

Education must start with the young. It is essential that the young people of Australia are aware of the facts about HIV and the risks of transmission and that they are sensitive to the issues which cause prejudice and fear. Accordingly, included in the funding for the States is an amount to be directed to the Curriculum Corporation of Australia, a company owned jointly by the State and Commonwealth Ministers of education. The Curriculum Corporation will assess and, where necessary, develop HIV-related curricula and provide teaching material for schools. By providing funds for this purpose, the Commonwealth is demonstrating its commitment to providing appropriate public health education to young Australians. A key issue which was identified by many groups in the consultative process was the need to provide educational opportunities for people in the work force, especially professional care givers.

A Commonwealth AIDS work force, information, standards and exchange, or CAWISE, program has been designed to ensure that the work force has access to information and resource materials, retraining and skills development programs and development of guidelines and standards. Grants will be provided to unions, professional and employee associations and employers. Funds have been earmarked for the development of guidelines on nutrition and HIV infection, a national code of practice for counsellors, and for a care model for Aboriginal and Islander people. Another new initiative, HIV study grants, to be cost shared with the States, will be available to professional care givers to undertake short term training and development in another State's hospital system. This will particularly give professional care givers in States with low AIDS caseloads an opportunity to learn on the ground from the experience of their colleagues in States and hospitals with high caseloads.

While education is a key preventive strategy which is critical to elimination of the virus, other prevention strategies require the agreement and cooperation of governments or relate to personal choices. Significant among these issues is testing for the virus. The Government will continue to encourage testing, with the specific informed consent of the individual and with pre- and post-test counselling. Knowledge of one's HIV status provides an opportunity to encourage change in lifestyle and behaviour and to provide the earliest possible treatment and care. Testing and counselling is already widely available, but could be made more so, and State governments will be asked to improve community access to testing with counselling by expanding the availability through family planning clinics and other community health centres. People whose activities place them at greater risk of infection will be strongly encouraged to fulfil their duty to be tested.

There are some situations where the public interest demands that people be prohibited from participation in certain activities unless they accept testing and are found to be negative. Such mandatory testing will continue to apply for donors of blood, tissue, organs and semen. The Government considers compulsory testing to be applicable in only four situations, namely:
testing of prisoners on exit from prison;
testing of persons charged with a sexual offence where requested by the alleged victim;
testing of a person where necessary to determine medical treatment of another person, for example, in providing treatment in the event of a needlestick injury; and
testing of a person suspected of being HIV-positive who is placing others at risk of infection.

In the last three situations, testing should be implemented as a last resort and should be ordered only by a judge in a closed court. This also applies in confining an individual who is wilfully or knowingly placing others at risk of infection and who is likely to continue to behave in such a way despite appropriate counselling. Hearings in such cases should be conducted in a closed court with restriction orders given for a fixed period and subject to rights of review and appeal.

Guidelines on the testing of patients for surgical procedures, based on the interim guidelines established by the Australian Health Ministers Conference earlier this year and endorsed by the Australian Medical Association, are set out in the national strategy. In essence, these guidelines state that testing should be encouraged where clinically relevant to the patient or where the patient is believed to be at high risk, and that such testing should be performed only with the patient's consent and with follow-up counselling if the result is positive. I and the medical profession are confident that when patients are advised of the relevance of the test in appropriate clinical situations, the response of patients will be overwhelmingly positive.

Some of the testing policies I have just outlined are primarily the responsibility of the States and require changes to legislation or, in some instances, new legislative measures. All these issues are to be examined by a subcommittee of the Inter-Governmental Committee on AIDS, comprising officers from the departments of Health and the Attorney-General, with a view to bringing consensus and uniformity to legislative initiatives arising from the national strategy. Rarely has there been so great a need for uniform policies through the nation. The virus does not recognise State boundaries. We should not allow such boundaries to interfere with an effective national response.
Other issues to be covered by the legal review include:
legal sanctions which impede the operation of needle and syringe distribution and disposal programs;
legal sanctions which might impede the changing of personal use patterns of drugs which are not administered by intravenous methods; and
laws which impede public health programs promoting safer sex, especially amongst homosexuals and prostitutes.

In considering the testing of immigrants to Australia, the national strategy makes a distinction between applicants for permanent residence and applicants for temporary residence and tourist or other short term visas.

In considering the testing of immigrants to Australia, the national strategy makes a distinction between applicants for permanent residence and applicants for temporary residence and tourist or other short term visas. People who wish to migrate to Australia are currently tested for the virus if there are medical or other indications of infection. The Government has decided that mandatory HIV testing will be introduced for all applicants for permanent residence. This is unlikely to have a significant impact on the spread of HIV infection, but HIV infection status, as with other medical conditions, is a factor to be considered when assessing applications on the grounds that there are considerable potential costs to the Australian community.

But a positive result will not automatically exclude applicants from permanent residency; scope will be retained to approve applications where justified by compassionate or other circumstances. I have already stressed the importance of avoiding discrimination against people with AIDS, but it remains a fact that many people with HIV, their relatives, friends and carers have faced discrimination. Some have been dismissed from employment, some evicted from accommodation, others refused medical or dental treatment or perhaps harassed by the media.

The Government is asking the States to establish, extend or clarify anti-discrimination legislation, to provide redress for people with HIV, their families and carers in basic areas such as employment, education and training, accommodation and supply of goods and services and to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or imputed sexual orientation. This issue will also be included in the legal review and will seek to ensure that people with HIV are treated fairly and equitably, and on the same basis as people with other life-threatening conditions. As a first step, the Commonwealth Government will bring forward amendments to section 33 of the Public Service Act and regulations under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act.

Research is vital to our understanding and knowledge of the AIDS virus and in the search for a vaccine or therapy. Grants for AIDS research have been managed through the Commonwealth AIDS Research Grant Committee, a subcommittee of the Government's AIDS advisory body, the Australian National Council on AIDS, known as ANCA. The two special research units on AIDS virology and AIDS epidemiology and clinical research will be continued under the auspices of ANCA, and the Government has decided to establish a third ANCA special research centre on HIV social research. The new centre will be responsible for coordinating research into the social and psychological effects of the epidemic, identifying further educational and training needs and examining the impact of projects and policy initiatives.

As part of our regional responsibility, Australia will publish results of AIDS research for dissemination within Australia and Western Pacific, South East Asian and Indian Ocean nations. A new national clinical/laboratory surveillance scheme will be promoted through the ANCA special research centre for AIDS epidemiology and clinical research to improve the data base on HIV infection in Australia. Some good has already come out of this terrible epidemic in that it has inspired an extraordinary level of international cooperation. Despite the many issues which divide humanity, we have all united in our defence against AIDS. Developed nations are assisting less developed nations to combat the disease, some in the form of financial assistance and others by providing medical and scientific expertise.

The Australian Government will provide $1m to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to provide help to our regional neighbours for activities such as securing the blood supply and study grants. In addition, Australia, in association with the World Health Organisation, will host a conference on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific in Canberra next August.

I have briefly outlined some of the major issues in the national HIV/AIDS strategy. There is an issue which remains to be resolved. The Government is further addressing the issue of special assistance to haemophiliacs affected by the HIV virus and a decision will be made and announced by mid October. The Government has allocated $318.5m over the next four years to implement the strategy. In this, the first year, funds of $60.9m have been made available, an increase of 43.6 per cent on the previous financial year. Details of these funds are included in the national strategy document.

In closing, I would like to thank everyone who has been involved in the preparation of the national strategy, including members of both Houses and all parties of this Parliament who have ensured that both the spirit and the practice of bipartisanship have been preserved. They have helped to formulate policies which put the public health of Australians above all other considerations, but which recognise the aspirations of all citizens of this country to a dignified and secure way of life, to a society which is free of prejudice and to a society which is caring, just and humane. Effectiveness of the national strategy will, of course, depend on cooperation between a wide range of sectors of Australian society, across the three levels of government, between government and non-government sectors, between unions and employers and between all these parties and people infected with the virus.

It would be somewhat ingenuous to believe that everyone will agree with all that is in this national strategy. As I said in my speech to the House in November, there will continue to be diversity of opinion between different States, different communities, different organisations and different individuals, and that diversity will be reflected in the range of programs established to respond to the virus. The Government believes that such diversity will continue to assist our national offensive against AIDS providing it is underpinned by a solidarity of purpose. Solidarity gives us the confidence to face up to the challenge of AIDS and deal openly and honestly with the difficult and controversial issues it presents. I commend the national HIV/AIDS strategy to the Parliament and to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy Speaker, let me preface my remarks by congratulating you on your election and elevation to high office, and go on to say very clearly and without qualification that the Liberal and National parties welcome the release of this White Paper. While all of those associated with its production would have wished that it could have appeared earlier, nevertheless let me say that on its release now I am prepared to make the comment that it is a landmark policy document in the field of public health in Australia, and indeed the world, and all of those associated with its production, from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) down, need to be, and should be, congratulated.

SPEECH.PARA: In the development of the production of this policy paper the Liberal and National parties have played a constructive and cooperative part. I was pleased personally to join with the Minister at a joint press conference when he released the Green Paper, which was the discussion paper which ultimately was to give rise to this policy White Paper. Individuals of the Liberal and National parties participated in a representative capacity at the meetings of the parliamentary liaison group and we will continue to do so for as long as we are in Opposition. We contributed to the working parties which toured around Australia gathering advice, evidence and input, which has gone into the drafting of this particular document and, indeed, by way of making almost a formal submission during that process we ourselves published the Liberal and National parties acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) policy in June of this year.

I am very pleased to be able to say that this Parliament and indeed the nation is in the happy position whereby the Liberal and National parties' AIDS policy published in June lines up very squarely with the White Paper and the reverse is also the case-the White Paper lines up very squarely with the published policy position of our joint parties in Opposition. The overriding goal of this policy is to eliminate the transmission of HIV infection to ensure that no more Australians than is the case now will be affected by AIDS. That is the overriding goal of our own policy. We endorse each and every one of the 10 guiding principles that guide this policy and the Minister covered them in his speech. We stand four square with the Government in recognising that AIDS is a major threat to public health in this country at the current time.

The Minister has documented the statistics that up until 9 August this year 733 people, or more than 50 per cent of Australia's 1,414 reported AIDS cases, have died. But these two statistics mark what is even more alarming out there in our community. Reliable estimates are that there are between 15,000 and 25,000 people infected with the HIV virus and our knowledge of the virus is such that we can now confidently conclude almost 100 per cent of those will go on to develop AIDS. Even if those statistics are a little overblown and we conclude that, say, there is half that number, 7,500 people, who are HIV infected in our community, we have a serious and major health problem on our hands.

Against that backdrop it is important to appreciate that the proper implementation of the White Paper's recommendations, its suggested strategies for halting the march of AIDS through the community, depends upon the Government having the courage to go beyond an agenda determined by the dictates of electoral cycles. We are likely to have a Federal election within the next 12 months, but HIV infection and AIDS is a crucial issue that the community cannot afford to have caught up in electoral planning. It needs a far more farsighted, long term response.

From the Government's point of view it is pleasing to see that the Minister has indicated that the policies and programs which are to be set in place are aimed at dealing with the HIV epidemic into the 1990s. From our point of view I want to repeat a comment that I made at a press conference this afternoon: with a change of government, which we expect in the next 12 months, these policies and this program will not be disturbed. We embrace the national strategy as if it were our own. While we do not commit ourselves at this stage to every detail contained in the document, it will be our guiding policy document when in government. While at this stage we do not commit ourselves to the legislation that the Government has yet to bring forward, the document will be our guiding policy document when in government.

Local and international experience identifies the principal weapons in the fight against HIV and AIDS as education and research. Local and international indications are that education programs targeted towards homosexual men have produced significant behaviour modifications, and they support the argument for preventive education as a major component of any national AIDS strategy. In Australia, as the Minister correctly pointed out in his speech, the homosexual community was responsible for the so-called first wave of HIV and AIDS, but it is no longer a disease which affects that community alone. National and international AIDS experts are unanimous that the threat of widespread transmission of AIDS into the general community is coming, and will continue to come, from intravenous (IV) drug users who, together with bisexuals, can act, and are acting already, as a bridge for the second wave of infection into the wider community. Therefore, it is imperative that every member of the community take active steps to avoid high risk behaviour and adopt safe sex practices as a means of protecting not only themselves but also other members of the community.

In common with the approach adopted by the Liberal and National parties in our policy document, the Minister has stated that the transmission of HIV is preventable through the modification of individual behaviour. This is the positive message to come out of this public health tragedy. Now that the Government and agencies have been successful in securing the public blood supply in this country, the good news in the AIDS story is that no-one currently uninfected need ever get it. If they understand how it is contracted, it can be avoided.

Central to bringing about these changes are effective education and prevention programs which are specifically tailored to successfully reach particular target groups and the community as a whole. As the Minister has reported, a great deal of work has already been done to deliver successful education programs to and within the homosexual community. The spread of HIV infection through bisexuals must also be actively addressed. Generally, men in stable heterosexual relationships who also engage in male homosexual intercourse from time to time do not identify with any homosexual or gay community. We need, in the context of this strategy, to ensure that the education message is reaching that sub-group of our community, because, whatever we may think about it from a moral point of view, we will not eliminate that sort of bisexual behaviour and from an AIDS perspective the education message must be carried to that group as well.

Sharing of needles and syringes between drug addicts has also been shown to be a major means of HIV transmission. Education must state that total abstinence from drug use is the first and best option. In confronting the whole drug problem and how it interrelates and interacts with the AIDS problem, we do not abandon the fight against drugs and drug addiction, but subsequent messages must reinforce that refraining from sharing drug equipment and the thorough cleansing of such equipment are essential to achieve protection from the risk of HIV infection.

The efficient transmission of infection by heterosexual activity has been clearly demonstrated by the African experience of AIDS. The important point I want to stress for Australians is that this has not come about simply as a result of poor genital health. I refer to the statistics which the Minister has cited on other occasions in relation to HIV infection in the United States. For example, in New York City AIDS is the biggest killer of women under 30 years of age and one in 60 babies is now born with the virus. These figures are a chilling foretaste of what could happen in this country. It therefore remains imperative that the whole community-I stress, the whole community-remains vigilant, that HIV and AIDS are not dismissed as a nine-day wonder, or not dismissed as belonging only to certain sub-groups in the community. We cannot allow the possibility of our becoming complacent about its potential to reach the wider community and, indeed, potentially to touch us all, if not directly, then certainly through our families and friends.

The verdict of scientists at the Fifth International Conference on AIDS held in Montreal, Canada, in June this year was that beyond any reasonable doubt the spread of AIDS has become a major life threatening reality for millions and millions of people. The bulk of those in greatest jeopardy are young people who, by virtue of their risky sexual and drug taking behaviour, are placing themselves in grave danger of becoming infected with the HIV virus. Therefore, school children and sexually active young people must also be the focus of preventive education campaigns. If we are complacent, if we neglect to communicate the risk of HIV infection to the nation's youth, we could see an uncontrolled epidemic into the year 2000 and beyond. The Opposition is very pleased to associate itself with a policy that sees the delivery of education at all levels, as mentioned by the Minister in his speech.

If the point needs reinforcing, AIDS is not a political issue. It is a public health issue requiring the utmost cooperation at all levels of government. Taking action against AIDS will not be an electoral plus. It will not win governments many brownie points. Dr Earl Berger, a senior AIDS policy adviser to the Canadian Government, has said, succinctly and pithily:
There are no votes in AIDS.

But any government or any opposition which fails to take or advocate appropriate action now could find itself accused of neglect when the 20-20 vision of hindsight which makes all of us wise men and women is brought to bear on what could well become a widespread epidemic and a national tragedy if we do not take the right action, and take it now.

It is a decade since AIDS was first identified. The Minister has referred to a paper which Jonathan Mann, the Director of the World Health Organisation's Global Program on AIDS, gave at the Montreal conference in June. In that paper Dr Mann revealed that as at 1 June this year a cumulative total of 157,191 AIDS cases from 149 countries around the world have been officially reported to the World Health Organisation. Dr Mann went on to add that the reporting is incomplete. The actual cumulative global total of AIDS cases is estimated at nearly half a million, or more than three times the number reported.

The epidemiology of the HIV infection gives a more complete and current view of the pandemic. Beginning this decade, 100,000 persons worldwide were infected with HIV. During the 1980s, five million to 10 million people around the world have become infected. If we take the conservative figure of five million and we spread that estimate around, we see that there are approximately 2 1/2 million cases in Africa, two million in the Americas, 500,000 in Europe and in our own part of the world-Asia and Oceania-about 100,000. The cumulative world total of AIDS cases is expected to double from today to the end of 1991-less than two years away-to over 1.1 million. One does not need any more statistical evidence to come to a conclusion that reinforces the view of both the Government and the Opposition in this country that intending migrants to Australia must be screened for AIDS. It is pleasing that the Government, which is currently responsible for the nation's migration policies, has adopted the view that we adopted in June in our policy. It is imperative that this health screening of migrants be implemented without delay in order not only to protect public health in this country but also to protect our budgets and the amount of money that we have available to spend on treating our own. We cannot afford to put ourselves in a position of importing HIV infection and then leaving Australian taxpayers open to the considerable cost of funding the care and treatment of those individuals. Quite frankly and bluntly put, we will have enough trouble looking after our own.

We are also pleased to recognise that the Government has again picked up a point in our policy-I do not seek to make a cheap point here; it might have adopted and come to this view independently-and is calling for the testing of prisoners before they go back into the community. Our prison system regrettably is an important conduit for HIV infection and prison inmates must be screened on their release to reduce their potential for threatening the health of the wider community.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about when they go in?

—Our own policy says that we should also test people when they go into gaol, and that is a minor point of difference between ourselves in this particular strategy although the Minister, to give him his due, recognises that the delivery of that is up to the State governments anyway. It does not matter what Minister Blewett might recommend, the acid will be on State health Ministers and police Ministers around the country. Let us put them on notice that our clear view is that there should be testing of inmates as they go into the penal system and testing of people as they are released. An important offshoot of that is that a proposed national prisons epidemiological study will provide important information to help contain the spread of HIV infection and AIDS. As I have said, we very strongly trust and hope that the States and Territories, which are responsible for prisons, will actively cooperate in the study and uniformly adopt pre-release testing as a bare minimum and preferably move towards testing on admission as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before-I cannot cover the entire report-that education programs aimed at homosexual men have achieved significant changes in behaviour in this country. The success of these programs has largely been due to their grassroots nature. Messages have been developed and delivered appropriate to the target group, and they are being presented in a way which is relevant to them and are coming from sources which have won their confidence and trust. On other occasions I have had the opportunity to speak with the Minister about this particular aspect, and I express at this stage some concerns that we have in prospect.

The real success of the Government's strategy so far in delivering education programs in this country in the fight against HIV infection and AIDS is that it learnt from its mistakes in the campaign against drugs. We collectively-that is, the taxpayers of this country-saw many millions of dollars wasted in that campaign. Governments are good at some things. The Commonwealth Government-I am sure that the public of this country will agree-is a very good taxer. We are good at raising money. We are also good at handing out dollops of money to State governments, local government and community organisations. We are good at coming up with policies. But we are not good at delivering programs or implementing strategies from Canberra. Equally, the same argument applies to the State government level. The State governments are good at policy; in their own way they are also good at raising money and handing out dollops of money. But in a whole range of areas they are not good at delivering programs, and in respect of the fight against AIDS and HIV infection they are not good at delivering the educative message that needs to be got across to the sub-groups in our community- homosexual men, bisexual men, IV drug users, prostitutes and other sex workers.

I appeal to the Minister: for as long as he and the Government have carriage of this policy they must continue with the strategy of funding community groups through the Commonwealth AIDS prevention and education program and the other programs mentioned in the detail of the policy. Quite frankly, they produce literature which, from my point of view and the point of view of many members and senators, is quite shocking. But that is not the point. They deliver the education message from within and to their peer group in a way that is relevant and which the Minister has recognised is working. We have to have the courage of our convictions, within appropriate guidelines and appropriate checks, and continue to do that in respect of IV drug users and sex workers. I do not stand Buckley's chance of trying, as a prospective Commonwealth Health Minister, to convince people that they should not share needles, but it is those people who share needles with them who may stand a chance. We have to fund their arm, as it were, and ensure that the education message is developed and targeted in the best way and gets to the people who need to hear it in a way they will understand and, importantly, accept. I personally will be constantly looking for any bureaucratisation or any bureaucratic moving in on the funding of these programs because that is not the way to go.

The Minister briefly mentioned that the Government is giving further consideration to special groups that have been infected by the HIV virus and AIDS. Of course, foremost of those is the haemophiliac group in this country. Currently 400 Australian families of haemophiliacs are facing up to the problem of HIV infection contracted, tragically, through essential treatment but involving contaminated blood products. They were contaminated before we had even heard about the virus. I simply say to the Minister publicly across the table that we on this side of the House hope that the Government will give very serious, detailed and compassionate consideration to the claims that are being made on it by this particular group in our society.

Akin to the remarks I made about the delivery of the education message, I also want to say that in implementing its national strategy we sincerely hope that the Government will heed the warnings of its former chief adviser on AIDS, Professor Tony Basten, who said that too much money is being spent on committees and meetings and too little on research. Professor Basten also claimed that the bureaucracy had taken too long to act on key anti-AIDS strategies. We need to ensure that we do not waste time and do not waste money.

Finally, another area to be resolved is the whole area of research and developing a foolproof non-reusable syringe. The Government has mentioned this responsibly. The jury is still out on this technology. We say to the Government that we hope it will pay very close attention to the need to continue to fund research into the development of this technology because the prevention of the re-use of syringes is one of the best ways of inhibiting increased community infection via IV drug users. Perhaps a foolproof non-re- usable syringe will be a key element in that particular area. Safer syringes could also eliminate needle stick injuries, which pose a threat to health care workers.

All in all, we welcome the White Paper as a blueprint for dealing with HIV infection and AIDS on the basis of what is currently known about the infection and the disease. But the importance-one might even say the beauty-of the strategy is that as our knowledge bank improves and increases the strategy also allows for development and improvement. The paper represents a sensible balance between the interest of the public health of the community and the need for care and compassion in the treatment of those already affected by the disease. We are pleased, in a no-nonsense way, to offer bipartisan support for the initiatives which the Minister has outlined, but we place the Minister and the Government on notice that we will monitor progress and, where and when necessary, make known apparent deficiencies in the interests of the wider community.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy which has led to the massive disruption caused by the airline pilots' dispute.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me start by putting the record straight. The Opposition does not accept the rantings and ravings that we had from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Question Time and his attempts to put the blame for this pilots strike on the Opposition. I have a pretty simple message for the Prime Minister: `Listen, mate, this is your policy. You have revved up this dispute'. I can tell the Prime Minister that he will be wearing the consequences of the damage that the dispute will cause this country. It is no good for him to come in here with his Pontius Pilate attitude and say, `I wipe my hands of the whole thing'. That will not wash. I can tell the Prime Minister that his claim that this is an example, a microcosm, of the Opposition's policy is nonsense and deserves to be exposed. One would think that we had been in government for the last seven years. The only thing I can say about that is that: if we were in government things would not be in the mess they are in today.

SPEECH.PARA: On this first day back in the Parliament after the escalation of the pilots dispute we have initiated this debate just to get a few things on the public record. Firstly, we wish to expose the gross irresponsibility of the Prime Minister, whose personal intervention has clearly escalated this dispute to the situation today where it is hard to see an end in sight. Secondly, we wish to direct the underlying causes of this dispute where they rightly belong-at the feet of the Government's failed accord and its centralised wage system and to condemn the Government for perpetuating this system when reforms of the sort proposed by the Opposition are so obviously required. Lastly, through the contribution of my colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull)-I might say that he is generally recognised by honourable members on both sides of this House as being an expert in tourism and aviation matters-we will try to get the message through to the Government that this dispute has already irreparably damaged our economy and not just the airline industry but also the very important tourist industry.

The reactions of the Prime Minister have been nothing less than incredible. The hypocrisy of this man seems to know no bounds. He might think that this will give him some sort of window of opportunity for an early election on the basis that, like the old days, he would start the fire and, hey presto, he would come in with the fire brigade, the hose in his hand. The fact is that there will be no kudos, no political marks, for the Government from the way in which this dispute is going for the simple reason that the damage that will be caused to our economy will be so great that no-one will be thanking the Prime Minister for his personal intervention. He really is completely out of touch if he thinks that, at the end, people's gratitude for his personal intervention will somehow flow over into the ballot box at the next general election.

Whatever his motive, there is no doubt that he has been so desperate to escalate this dispute that he has abandoned, denied, walked away from virtually all of his previous announcements on industrial relations. This is the man who, in July 1986, said:
I don't believe that better industrial relations are brought about by the method of harsh legal sanctions.
He has done a 180-degree turn and, just a few days ago, said:
I say without equivocation-
that ought to make honourable members worry-

that when the airlines decide to initiate these legal processes with significant very drastic financial penalties against individual pilots and their organisation the airlines will be pursuing those legal processes with the full support of my Government.

This is the same bloke who in 1974 supported a 27 per cent wage increase for international airline pilots. This is the same bloke who parades around this country as the high priest of consensus. Yet just a few days ago there he was on the media declaring war, for heaven's sake, on the pilots. Instead of looking for some solution to this problem, instead of looking to his beloved industrial relations system to find a solution, instead of taking a deep breath and asking himself `What would be in the national interest in this case?', he sits down with his minders, gets a can of petrol and starts pouring it on the flickering flames. On Saturday, 19 August, he had the Commonwealth support a cancellation of the pilots award. He must have known that that action could do nothing other than stiffen the pilots' resolve. They do not want to have anything to do with the award and his system. On the Sunday, after years of trying to prevent people from having access to common law actions, he was making pronouncements supporting common law action against the pilots.

I heard him on Melbourne radio on Monday and he really went berserk. He started pushing the line that anyone could fly an aeroplane-it was the same as learning a trade, as if honourable members would be happy to have their local plumber fly them in and out of Canberra. He said that it was no more responsible than driving a bus and that he-Captain Rambo Hawke-would make the pilots regret that they had ever heard of flying. We know that he can fly a kite. We have heard that he had lessons in a Chipmunk and he might have had a refresher course from Biggles Evans in the other place; but he really ought to understand that it takes a lot of skill to be a modern pilot. Quite frankly, it is no help whatsoever in trying to settle this dispute to have the Prime Minister attempting to belittle the pilots. Apparently, he had Ted Harris on the phone ticking him off for escalating the dispute.

We have had reports about senior Ministers. Perhaps the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) will get up and say what he told the Prime Minister about the escalation of this dispute. In the Australian the other day Richard Farmer quoted one pilot who I thought put it pretty well. He said:
Hawke gave us the Araldite to stick together.

He was not joking. When the letters went out from the airline companies the pilots were already galvanised by the Prime Minister's remarks. They had their chain telephone system so cranked up as a result of his remarks that within 11 hours-from 3 p.m. one afternoon to 2 a.m. the next day-they had 1,640 letters of resignation in their hip pockets ready for delivery to the airline companies the next morning. As we all know, ever since then the whole system has been at a standstill. The fact is that the Prime Minister has deliberately escalated this dispute and, as the damage bill mounts, he stands condemned for his actions in exacerbating this dispute.

Before proceeding to analyse the failures of the Government's industrial relations policy, let me just make clear our attitude to the pilots. The Opposition does not have much time for the pilots. They have a double-barrelled shotgun pointed at the head of this economy and they have already pulled one of the triggers. This is the classic Aussie dispute. This is the way we run industrial relations in this country. We have a union with strong industrial muscle running amuck, inconveniencing the public-which is one of its favourite levers-and, as a result, we are seeing the country going broke. Today Moody's Investors Service Inc.-as if we needed to hear the message again-is downgrading our credit rating. Why? Because we do not run industrial relations very well in this country. It is about time that we started to recognise the causes of our very poor industrial relations system.

In analysing this issue let me once again dismiss that propaganda and make it clear that Labor's industrial relations policy carries the blame for what is happening. Just to add to it, today at Question Time the Prime Minister was talking about the Qantas dispute. I do not know the details but he was actually revving up. He did not say it but he might as well already have declared war on the Qantas pilots. If they were not going to go out, I reckon he has certainly increased the chances of their doing so. People would ask, `Why is it that the Prime Minister takes this view?'. One of the reasons that the Government sees this as a threat to its centralised system is that every wage increase must fit within the deals worked out behind closed doors between Mr Kelty and Mr Keating. They call it comparative wage justice. It is one of the principles of which they are very fond. No-one can move in this country without Bill Kelty's approval. The whole system has been established, set up and maintained to deliver control to the ACTU hierarchy, and under this system all wages and conditions, as best as they can organise it, must be related one to the other. Not only has their abject failure been in terms of perpetuating this dispute; with award restructuring, the Government actually wants to worsen the situation; it wants to give us a more centralised, more rigid, more inflexible system than this country has ever had. It is a point that the Minister for Industrial Relations recognises. I will give him his credit. He said to Bill Kelty that he was a bit worried about the inflexibility of the lower wage proposals, and Bill Kelty went straight to the Treasurer and this Minister, for good measure, had Bill Kelty get his scribe, Pamela Williams, to do him over in the Australian Financial Review, to say what a hopeless Minister he was.

The fact is that this Government is intent on maintaining its centralised system regardless of the consequences. The mechanisms which established this system of rigidity and centralisation are principally the structure of awards and the structure of unions. Union structure encourages the system to deliver the same wage outcome in every enterprise in the country regardless of the circumstances of the enterprise. The Government has encouraged bigger unions with bigger muscle. It has failed to reduce the number of unions in individual enterprises. The award structure complements that process and carries the same result. The Government has failed to promote tailor-made enterprise agreements.

All this means that Labor's industrial relations system is a recipe for break-outs-and, of course, we have them; we have them regularly under the centralised system. They are a product of the industrial relations systems in this country, and the entrenchment of comparative wage justice has a whole lot of other adverse consequences, one of which is that if people work better, if they work more efficiently, there is no reward for it. We do not have a system of incentive. People want to know why we have such an appalling productivity record compared to all our competitors. I call it the yawning productivity gap-we are going down and everybody else is going up.

Why is it, then, that we have that? One of the principal reasons is that in this centralised rigid system we cannot introduce a means of paying people which will encourage productivity. What flows from that? Not only do we have this poor productivity performance; we have the Government running a low wage policy. On top of that, we have resentment building up, and people resent having their standards of living reduced. So what do we get? We get a vicious circle operating, so we get these unreasonable and unaffordable demands for pay increases.

To add insult to injury, our arbitration system is a toothless tiger. Let us look at what has happened in the pilots dispute. The Industrial Relations Commission directed a return to work-and the pilots say `Get lost', `Drop dead'. Why should anyone be surprised? We have been running the system like that for years. It is a one-sided system. If people do not like what the Commission, the umpire, says, they can just walk away from it. That is one of the central features of this system under Labor's failed accord and failed industrial relations policy. The Government has conceded this point. There is no great intellectual fight between us and the Government. The Government actually introduced a Bill in 1987 to give us a decent system of enforcement in our industrial relations system-and what happened? It had on the other side a proposal to do away with section 45d, which the Prime Minister now reckons is the greatest thing since sliced bread. So we find Crean saying, `No, you cannot have a decent enforcement procedure in the Act'. They admitted it; they conceded the ground; and in the end they did not have the political will, the political determination to do what is in the national interest to improve our industrial relations system.

The hypocrisy of this Government is just mind-boggling. The Prime Minister talks tough; we heard lots of tough talk today. But he is not prepared to toughen up his own industrial relations system. He supports the system, but he is not prepared to do anything to improve it, although those reforms are so very clear. By way of contrast, he capitulates to the wharfies at the drop of a hat. The rorts are worth $850m a year. It is the same with the meat workers. There are many examples. With the pilots there is a different attitude, and we are to be taken to the brink of ruin. It will be a long drawn out battle, where the only body that could arbitrate a decision stands idle on the sidelines rendered impotent by the Government's failure to adopt our sanctions Bill.

Once the problems are identified, the solutions become clear. We ought to do something about union structure. We ought to have a situation where there is only one union in each enterprise in the country. The Government ought to do something about our award structure, both within the Commission, so that we have an enterprise focus, and in the system of voluntary agreements, to allow and encourage people to sit down and talk on a one to one basis and improve industrial relations in every enterprise in this country. We should abandon the `big is beautiful' theory of the Keltys of the world and the megalomania that goes with it.

We condemn the Prime Minister for revving up this dispute. We condemn the Government's failed industrial relations policy for being the prime causal factor in the bringing about of this dispute. The Opposition makes a final appeal to the parties in the national interest. The Government ought to drop its political agenda, it ought to sit down and start to give some direction and start searching for some solutions for a problem which is going to cause real damage to our economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think anybody listening to that speech could only hear the ultimate in hypocrisy coming from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) when he accused the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of hypocrisy. It is the same old record, round and round. We have heard it ad nauseam. Nothing new; the same old story, a little bit out of date. But anybody listening on air this afternoon to that can only come to one conclusion: that the Opposition is supporting the Australian Federation of Air Pilots in the damage that it is doing to the aviation industry and to the tourism industry of this country. Have no doubt about that. The tone of questions from the Opposition in Question Time and the tone of the contribution by the honourable member for Flinders leave one very clear conviction in mind: that the Opposition is supporting the pilots on the path that they are on.

SPEECH.PARA: The disruption to Australia's air services by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is both irresponsible and unnecessary. This approach by the Federation of Air Pilots is a gun to the head of Australia approach. It is an approach that will not be accepted or tolerated by this Government. It is obviously encouraged by the tone of comment that comes from the Opposition and the policy they espouse. What the Federation is saying to the people of Australia is this: `Give us a 30 per cent pay increase, or else. Or else, we will ground air services in this country and we will wreck air services and the tourism industries of this country'. That is what they are saying, and they are getting encouragement from the Opposition in that course.

The Government's clear preference was that this matter should be pursued by the Federation of Air Pilots through the Industrial Relations Commission, in the proper process, like other wage and salary earners. The Federation made it very clear repeatedly that its members were not going to be party to that process, that they wanted to go outside the system, as they are encouraged to do by the Opposition's policy. They wanted to go outside the system, and now they are outside the system, totally. The comments made by the honourable member for Flinders regarding sanctions are utterly irrelevant. The sanctions that they talked about had relation to people operating within the system. In this case there is no strike; the pilots have resigned. We have got to have employees and employers. If the Opposition is going to apply sanctions to that, then we have got to have the employees back in the system, so let us not have any more of this humbug going on about what the Opposition's sanctions Bill might have done.

The fact is that what we have in this country today is a shining example of what we would have across the board, industry after industry, workplace after workplace, if the industrial relations policy of the Opposition were to be implemented. It is very simple and very clear. This is exactly what the Opposition is promoting. It is the Opposition's policy. Having told people to go outside the system, now that they are outside the system, it is saying that they ought to go back inside it and the Government ought to be doing something about legislating to deal with them when they are back inside the system. The policy that is being pursued by the Federation of Air Pilots is that which the Opposition is promoting. It cannot have it both ways. It usually wants a dollar each way, but it wants industry outside the system and firms outside the system. The Federation is outside. That is where the Opposition wants it to be. From comments made by members of the Opposition this afternoon it obviously supports the course being followed by the pilots.

I return to the conflict within the Opposition. It is very difficult for anybody who has been trying to follow what has been happening in recent weeks to know just where the Opposition stands on this issue. Its policy encourages what is happening. On 23 August the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said:

. . . we hear this nonsense proposition that the airline dispute is just `the free market doing its thing'-as if the unbridled use of coercive power and brute force is fundamental to our policy and to the operations of truly free markets.
The next day the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt) said:
. . . the belligerent attitude of the Prime Minister is a politically expedient `band-aid' approach that fails to address Australia's long-term labour market problems.
That is going in a different direction again. On the morning of 25 August the Leader of the Opposition said:
It's a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer-employee fight and look after the national interest. And the Government is correct.
Later, on 25 August, when asked how often he would need to use the proposed sanctions of the Bill-the failed sanctions Bill of the Opposition-he said:
I think that in fact, you might only have to use that sort of power once in a decade.

That goes to the trivia of what the Opposition is about. The Leader of the Opposition says that once in a decade we might use that power. He had previously said that the Government was correct. The Leader of the National Party says something different. Then Senator Chaney, that nice gentleman who likes to have something each way, says we should leave it to the employer and the employee to sit down and work it out themselves. Today the Opposition is saying that that is not right, that the Government should be fixing it. This is the confusion that comes from this. Senator Chaney says:
. . . our industrial relations system is aimed at allowing market forces greater operation, but giving a real prospect of increased productivity which can underpin real wage increases.
On the 7.30 Report of 22 August he said:
The pilots and employers could, I believe, work out a better arrangement than they've got at present. That is up to them.
They are out of the system. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), has a different view from that. At the National Press Club a couple of days earlier he said:
You wouldn't be getting a claim of that size under our system.

All I can say to the Opposition is that it is time it worked out exactly what its policy is and tried to get some consistency within it. It has to accept that what is happening here in this dispute is its policy in practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —What am I going to tell the Tasmanians?

—The honourable member should tell them to write to his great leader. We come back to the old story about attacking and denigrating the accord-the failed accord, as the Opposition puts it. The failed accord has produced 1 1/2 million new jobs in this country. It is the accord which has produced what the Opposition does not really like-a 60 per cent reduction in the rate of industrial disputation. It cannot accept that. That is a major achievement of the accord. Under the accord we have seen a containment of wages costs. The pilots are saying that they want a 30 per cent increase. The Opposition says the pilots should sit down and have a yarn with the employers and work something out-30 per cent, that should be all right.

SPEECH.PARA: That kind of reaction and that kind of process would quite clearly produce a wages explosion, rampant inflation, a collapse of the economy and a massive increase in unemployment. The people of Australia understand that. They understand the risks and dangers of what the pilots are about. They understand the risks and dangers of what the Opposition's policy means in practice. Similarly, industry understands that. It is not supporting the enterprise by enterprise arrangement that the Opposition is talking about. They are hands on people. They have to deal with the practicality of running businesses. They know that if the policy put by the Opposition were to come into practice there would be a wages explosion. There would be an eruption of strikes across the country as one pressure group sought to grab gains for itself and was followed by another pressure group in a similar circumstance. That clearly indicates the futility of the Opposition's policy.

At the beginning of my remarks I said that the Government wanted this matter to be dealt with through the ordinary processes within the system. The Federation of Air Pilots did not see it that way. It has gone outside the system now. It is simply a matter of employees talking individually to their employers. The airlines have advertised for pilots in the process of recruiting new staff. They have had a substantial response to those advertisements, especially from younger pilots and pilots abroad. I hasten to add that one would not be surprised if there were a response from their former pilots. It is a matter of those discussions taking place under the Opposition's policy-employee to employer, one to one, and not as the Federation of Air Pilots. The Federation of Air Pilots is irrelevant in this dispute.

I return to what the Opposition has said about its failed Bill on sanctions and the compliance package in the 1987 Bill. The constant claim made by Senator Chaney, and made earlier this afternoon by the honourable member for Flinders, is that the package in that Bill was dropped because of union pressure. That has been claimed many times by the Opposition and it is absolutely untrue. There is no truth whatsoever to it. The 1987 Bill contained a total compliance package. It provided for enforceable directions by the Commission through an injunctions process. It also limited access to other legal remedies outside the system. That package was not opposed by the union movement; it was opposed by the employers. On 6 June the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), announced that the compliance provisions of the Bill would be amended. Mr Willis emphasised that the system would not work without the commitment of the parties. The employers would not accept the original compliance package. The unions would not accept only those parts of the package which had employer support. For those reasons the compliance provisions of the 1987 Bill were amended to retain the bans clause process from the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, to remove any restriction on access to the common law and to retain unchanged the processes for dealing with secondary boycotts under the Trade Practices Act. The intention to amend the 1987 Bill in this manner was announced in detail by Minister Willis on 6 June 1987.

I repeat that the claim by Senator Chaney that the 1987 compliance package was dropped because of union pressure is patently false. It is absolutely false. He knows that to be true. The matter put by the Opposition in respect of the relevance of the compliance package to this dispute to the pilots withdrawing their services and resigning, is irrelevant. The sanctions have no relevance at all. As I mentioned earlier, the pilots have resigned. They are no longer employees. There is no place for them within the system. Their bleating is irrelevant. The Federation of Air Pilots was absolutely resolute. It wanted to be outside the system, despite the view of the company and the Government to the contrary. It is now dealing with an environment which is totally different from what it expected. It now has to live with the consequences. As individuals the pilots have to find their way back. They can only be encouraged by the questions asked and the comments made this afternoon by the Opposition in this place. They can only be encouraged, to the great damage of Australia's tourism and airline industries.

I conclude by returning to what is the real aggro, the real concern, the matter that drives the Opposition most, and that is its anger with the accord because it is working. Real unit labour costs are down some 14 per cent under this Government. Employment is at its lowest level over seven years at 6.1 per cent. Gross domestic product growth was at 3.3 per cent in 1988-89 and 1 1/2 million new jobs have been created as a result of the wage restraint that has been experienced through the processes of the accord. Within that accord and the Government's legislation there is provision for, firstly, control of wages policy and restraint of wages and, secondly, the flexibility that is needed, through certified agreements, through sections 115 and 118, to provide for unique circumstances and needs in certain places of employment. We have a double system which represents the best of both worlds: a centralised wage system-control over wages as an essential element of economic policy-and the flexibility to provide for improvement and unique circumstances. Added to that, which is what the Opposition does not want to understand, are the advantages and gains to be made in productivity through the award restructuring process. That process is well under way. It is something that cannot be contemplated by the Opposition and the Opposition does not want to understand it. It is in that orderly process that we will get a more flexible and better skilled work force-a work force that can make Australian industry more efficient and competitive. We will do that without the confrontation, division and fragmentation proposed in the policies being pursued by the Opposition. What we are seeing with the current air services problem and the actions of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots are examples of the Opposition's industrial relations policy at work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by making three statements of fact: firstly, tourism is Australia's biggest export earner and earned $6.5 billion last year; secondly, tourism, after the Public Service, is Australia's biggest employer, with 450,000 people; and, thirdly, the present industrial policies of the Government and the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are sending tourism broke and providing the unemployment pile with literally tens of thousands of people, because of the Government's completely inept attitude towards the pilots strike and the Prime Minister's reluctance to take any form of leadership whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to bring to the attention of the House the daily news bulletin of what is happening in the tourist industry. I will get through the figures, which are the most up to date available, State by State. On Queensland's Gold Coast, which is now allegedly enjoying its peak period, already there have been 7,000 cancellations of conventions and group bookings. Last Friday 2,200 convention delegates dipped out-they cancelled-at a cost of $3m. The average loss on the Gold Coast is raging at $2.5m a day. The five-star hotels on the Gold Coast have an occupancy rate of 13 per cent. Three major conventions were cancelled at one hotel alone in Brisbane. Brisbane is losing 4,000 to 5,000 delegates per week on existing conferences. Hotel bookings are down to a 20 per cent occupancy rate. In Cairns the immediate cancellations of groups and conventions are costing $2m a day and more cancellations are coming in daily.

At this time of the year there is normally a 100 per cent occupancy rate in hotels in Ayers Rock. The rate is down to 40 per cent and one major conference has already gone. Adelaide City alone is losing $3.2m a day because of the strike. If it goes on it will lose much more than that. The occupancy rate at Adelaide hotels at the moment is 25 per cent and there have been staff lay-offs. All hotel bookings in Canberra are down 30 per cent. Seven conferences have already been cancelled and the occupancy rate stands at 20 per cent. In Tasmania tourism has stopped altogether because there are virtually no air services. Hotel occupancy rates are at less than 20 per cent. The marginal operations of motor homes and rental cars-Tasmania's biggest area-have virtually stopped. Staff are being laid off. The Tasmanian economy has been shot to pieces to the tune of $550,000 per day. In Western Australia bookings are down by 50 per cent. Last week the Hyatt Regency Hotel lost $250,000. The Observation City complex lost $630,000 and is working on a 10 per cent occupancy rate. Every domestic tourist going to Western Australia is worth $580. So far it is costing the Western Australian economy $2.5m per week. The Burswood Resort in Perth lost $300,000 in cancelled convention traffic. In Broome the Cable Beach Resort is losing $50,000 per day. That is the story in tourism. People might ask, `What is happening in Victoria?' I can tell them that the Victorian Government is so good that it has wrecked the Victorian Tourism Commission to such an extent that nobody in the Victorian Tourism Commission can say what the figures are; they just do not know. That shows its real commitment to tourism.

What happened was that the Prime Minister saw an ideal opportunity to get an election issue running. It took him about two years to get the Builders Labourers Federation off the books, but he was into the pilots after 20 hours. We do not condone what the pilots did, but we have reached the stage where the tourist industry is being crippled and it will continue to be crippled.

Let us look at the latest report from the inbound tour operators of Australia. Today there were six cancellations of tours from one Japanese company. Further cancellations are expected following a big news article which appeared on the front page of Japanese newspapers last weekend. There were another seven cancellations from another company today, worth $1.2m, comprising three groups from Japan and four from Europe. A group of 93 from the United States, worth $500,000, has cancelled and another group has cancelled its trip to Lizard Island. Guess where it has gone! It has gone to Bali. Hotel occupancy rates should be at 80 per cent at this time of the year, but they are down to 30 per cent. The picture is one of disaster and gloom. There have been stand-downs and people are suffering. Yet we have seen nothing from the Prime Minister which will indicate that there is room to move or that he is prepared to undertake some role in trying to get the dispute resolved.

It is an established fact in the aviation industry that the airlines expect this strike to go on for as long as two months. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots will say that it has strike money which will last for eight months. Are we to see the total destruction of Australia's biggest export industry because the Prime Minister is looking for an election issue? That is really what it is all about. But he has been caught. He has got himself into a corner and there is no room to move. At the very least we should be promoting talks. The pilots should at least get together with the airline companies. Let Hawke and the Government get out of it and let us see whether we can get some rational discussions going. Under the failed industrial relations system that operates under the Government, nothing is working at the moment and nothing is likely to work for the next two months. We hope that the period I have cited will not be correct but, by golly, it looks as if it will be.

We saw an amazing performance by the Prime Minister today. He minced in here like a latter day Duke of Plaza-Toro. When we asked him a question about the deal that was done with Qantas Airways Ltd he went off his face completely. If he has done anything he has probably kindled the fire from a perfectly rational proposition to making sure that there is the possibility of an industrial dispute with Qantas. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) has just raged on about what we said in Question Time in terms of alternative services. The Government has had the Opposition's support in bringing in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). I might say that the Government was very game to do that. The last government that brought in the troops to break strikes was the Chifley Government in 1949. It lost the following election, as the Hawke Government will lose the next election.

The Government was supported by the Opposition in bringing in the RAAF. We were supportive on interlining and bringing in foreign carriers. Yet when we asked a simple question today about the prospect of charter airlines coming in, and about the safety requirements of those charter airlines, we got from the Prime Minister the greatest pooh-pooh that we have ever seen. I understand that there are at least three DC8 aircraft waiting to be chartered by Australian domestic airlines. I want an absolutely ironclad guarantee from the Government that if we are to go to the cowboy operators in the United States, when those aircraft are involved not necessarily with freight but with carrying passengers, they will have the right certification and be safe.

Earlier I referred to Arrow Air. I think that I did so with every justification because at the weekend a deal was quickly snuck through the Civil Aviation Authority. Admittedly, they are only charter aircraft, but I understand that the DC8s that are being offered could well come from Arrow Air. As I said in Question Time today, it has one of the worst safety records in the United States of America. For example, I quote from Canadian Aviation Safety Board report 85-H50902 on the crash of an Arrow Air DC8-63 at Gander in Newfoundland on 12 December 1985, resulting in the loss of 256 passengers and crew. The findings of the Canadian Aviation Safety Board were that the aircraft was not de-iced prior to take-off. There was a partial loss of engine thrust in the No. 4 engine and the integrity of a class D cargo compartment was also involved. The flight was undertaken with two missing side panels in the No. 3 cargo pit; the take-off weight calculated by the crew was 14,000 pounds less than the actual weight of the aircraft; the take-off speeds used by the crew may have been as much as 35,000 pounds less than the actual take-off weight; and the actual weight of the passengers was not reflected in the calculations and accurate weight and centre of gravity calculations were not being performed by flight crews for every flight. The maximum design zero fuel rate of the aircraft was exceeded on each of the Arrow Air troop charters in December 1985. Arrow Air's contractual obligations with respect to authorised payload capacity exceeded the authorised payload capacity of that aircraft being used. Arrow Air flight crews were not recording all aircraft unserviceabilities in the aircraft journey logs and on occasion were accepting for flight aircraft with known defects. The aircraft's flight recorders were not up to date, and the crew had been working 15 hours on the stick that day, with a work load of 20 hours over a 24-hour period. Yet the Prime Minister and this Minister wonder why we raise these matters.

We must make sure that in these emergency procedures there is absolute safety for the Australian travelling public. But this Minister comes in here and preaches to us with that garbage that he just gave us, while the tourist industry is bleeding, while the aviation industry is bleeding, and while millions of dollars are being taken offshore by the foreign carriers operating in Australia. We are in real strife and unless we get some leadership from this Government, unless we get some indication that the two parties can talk, if we are subjected--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, we have been hearing from two rather ranting and raving honourable members. I refer not so much to the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who gave us a travelogue on what is happening in the tourism industry within this country, but to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who very quickly is becoming known as ranting and raving Reith. SPEECH.PARA: The pilots are providing the Opposition with exactly what it wants-that is, no accord, just a dog eat dog environment in which the strong will survive and the weak will perish. I suppose that under the Opposition, if people are considered to be employed in an essential industry, as the pilots consider themselves to be, we could end up with a different sort of two-tier system. In fact we could have a system where those who believe that they play a more essential part in the community could make outrageous pay claims. The Opposition should come clean. It is no good coming in here, as the honourable member for Flinders and the honourable member for Fadden did, and talking about such things as what is happening in the tourism industry. We are not stupid; we know what is happening in the tourism industry. We do not need to have the honourable member for Fadden come in here and tell us the occupancy rates in Cairns or in Adelaide or anywhere else. We all know that this is hurting the country. That is the reason that we must do what we are doing. A personal attack on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as we heard in the speech of the honourable member for Flinders-in fact that was all it was; it was just a personal attack on the Prime Minister-is not going to solve this problem. What we need here is some help from everywhere. Instead, the Opposition is coming in and wasting the time of this House, of this Parliament, on a matter of public importance which is nothing short of a cheap political exercise. It is trying to turn a very serious issue which is sending our economy down the tube, which is going to result in massive stand-downs, which is going to result in people who are probably on much less money than what the pilots want in terms of the rise having to live with nothing or on the unemployment benefit because of stand-downs-that is what is happening in this country-into a personal attack on the Prime Minister.

The Australian Federation of Air Pilots wanted this fight last year. This has been a deliberate tactic by the pilots to bring this country to its knees if necessary so that they can go outside the wages system-outside the accord which has been in existence now for some seven years, which has definitely worked and which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) did say has caused a reduction in industrial disputation of up to 60 per cent. What they are saying is, `We are a group of professional people who are needed in the community and we want what we want, nothing less'. The 29.4 per cent that they are after is not an ambit claim. They have made it clear in all their correspondence with the airline companies, in all their negotiations, that that is non-negotiable. Mr Deputy Speaker, the fact is that everybody recognises that the pilots of this country are a very important group of professional people. There is no doubt about that. But there are many other groups of people in this society who are also very important. What difference in real terms is there between the aircraft maintenance people, for instance, who get the planes in the air, and the people who fly? I do not want to denigrate the pilots and I will not, because frankly we all respect pilots as much as we respect doctors and other professional people. But just because they are in an essential industry, just because they are in a position in which, by withholding their labour, they are able to wreck the economy of this country, just because of the fact that they do not believe that they belong to the wages system and are prepared to opt out of it, irrespective of what that does to the economy, it does not mean that they can expect the public of this country to have any respect for them. The only way they are going to get any respect, in my opinion, is to come back to work, to do the right thing and to accept that they cannot be placed outside a system which has worked in this country for the last seven years and will continue to work well.

As I have said, I am surprised that the Opposition wants a debate on industrial relations. It certainly has not been one of its strong points in the past and if today is any evidence of what those opposite know about industrial relations and what they would do, then what I have just said is exactly correct-that is, they should be keeping their mouths shut on this issue. If anything, they should be trying to help the Government, trying to help the airline companies, by coming up with proper solutions and not trying to make cheap political capital out of it. The Minister at the table has made clear the amount of days that have been saved in terms of industrial disputation. Of course, all Opposition members want to do in the case of industrial relations is trot out another lousy piece of legislation which they know full well means nothing, particularly in the context of the pilots strike. As the Minister said, the fact is that they are out of the system; they resigned. It does not matter how many laws are written in the Industrial Relations Act; the fact is they have resigned and are no longer covered by the Act. Therefore, all this business about extra sanctions is just absolute rubbish. The Opposition simply wants to be able to smash industrial disputes and smash the unions. That is really what it is all about. That is what Opposition members are saying here. They are simply saying to us, `Look, if we were in government we would fix it all up'. How are they going to fix it all up? They are going to end up in the same situation, not only once but on countless occasions.

There are many other industries, such as the power industry, where essential services are involved. Yet they are prepared to break the wages system that we have at the moment. They are prepared to risk the wages policy that this country has enjoyed, as I said, simply to be able to turn around and say, `Your policies are no good, they are not working' and they cite as an example this one strike. The bulletin brought out by the Air Pilots Federation I think some time last year or this year was a deliberate tactic for war. The Opposition says that the Prime Minister has declared war. The Prime Minister has not declared war; the Australian Federation of Air Pilots has somehow conned its members, people who, I am sure, if they realised just what they are doing to this country, might well change their minds.

Yet we have here a copy of the financial planning letter that was sent out to all the pilots. Unfortunately there is not enough time to read this but honourable members would be absolutely astounded if they could do so. The letter talks about eating in instead of eating out as one way of saving money. I might tell the pilots that most people in this country eat in because they cannot afford to eat out as they are not getting $75,000 or $79,000 as an average wage. The letter goes on to say that if a pilot is the sort of person who does not like sitting around home and doing nothing he should go fishing or go and fix his car or do something like that. That is great stuff! While pilots are out there fishing there are people who are suffering and, as I said, are probably getting less than the total rise the pilots want and the economy of this country is going down the tube.

I implore people in the Pilots Federation who have any brains to look at what they are doing and stop causing this hardship. I say to the Opposition, `Instead of wasting the time of this House with this sort of stupid matter of public importance, tell us what you think we should be doing. Give us some constructive ideas'.
