If today's episode is not a support of the pilots in this dispute by the Opposition, I do not know what is. Let us have some sanity in this serious situation. I say to the Opposition, `Stop making political capital out of it; it does not become you'.

Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I add my congratulations to those of other members of this House to you on your election to the speakership today. We look forward to your occupying that position for many years to come. It gives me pleasure to resume the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 on behalf of the Government. In doing so, I add my comments to those of commentators, honourable members and the public on the 1989 Budget recently presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It is an excellent Budget. That is not just my opinion; it is the general opinion right around Australia. What best points to the achievements of this Budget is the fact that since this Government came to power we have turned a $9.6 billion Budget deficit, which was bequeathed to us by the former coalition Government, into a $9.1 billion surplus. That is a $19 billion turnaround in the space of six years. This is an economic tour de force for which our Government and our Treasurer deserve a great deal of commendation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to confine my comments to the aspect of the Budget with which I have had most to do, and that is the retirement incomes policy. This was one of the major aspects of the Budget and it has generated a great deal of interest and excitement around the community. The Chanticleer column of the Australian Financial Review of 16 August, the day after the Budget, had this to say about the retirement incomes aspect of the Budget:

The revolution this Government has now produced in retirement income and therefore fund management is now as great as anything else it has done, including its deregulation of the financial system . . . already the things Paul Keating has done to encourage private superannuation have produced a boom for the industry; last night's additions to those will turn it into a bonanza . . . it would mean that within about 15 years, the savings position of the nation will have been transformed to the point where foreign debt of the size we are all now so worried about will either disappear or become irrelevant. And what's more it will be long-term savings-not short-term bank accounts as would be encouraged by such measures as providing tax relief on interest income.

Of course, we all know who has been advocating that latter policy. I had the great pleasure of being a member of the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on retirement incomes, which was most ably co-chaired by your good self, Mr Speaker, and the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh). As you would know, all of us-the 11 Government backbenchers on that committee-had a very interesting and fruitful time travelling around the country talking to groups of people and individual retired people about what they thought our retirement incomes policy should be and, in particular, gauging their response to the Cass report on retirement incomes. We raised many points and when we made our report to the Prime Minister we emphasised those points. I am very pleased to be able to say that many of the grievances which were expressed by retired people around the country have since been addressed either in the April economic statement or in this Budget.

The four aspects which Professor Bettina Cass nominated as characterising a good retirement incomes policy were adequacy, fairness, security and sustainability. On the question of adequacy, this Budget provides a special real rise of $2 a week from April 1990; that is, $2 for single pensioners and $3.30 a week for couples. Many people have been saying that this is not a large amount but it is the first real rise in pension incomes for many years. In April 1990 pensioners will get not only that rise but also their normal indexation rise. For a single pensioner this will amount to about $14 a week. Also in December of this year rent assistance will increase by $5 a week, with an extra $5 a week increase to follow, for beneficiaries with no children. In June 1990 there will be another $5 per week increase in rental assistance and an extra $5 per week for families with three or more children. In September 1990 there will be yet another $5 per week general increase and from March 1991 there will be six-monthly indexation of rental assistance.

The second aspect deemed as being essential to a good retirement incomes policy is fairness. Our credentials on fairness are already well established, principally through our policy of targeting assistance and social security payments to those who most need them. We do this largely in the area of age pensions, through the assets test and through the income test. It is important that all groups of retired people, whether they be on a full age or service pension or on superannuation with maybe a part pension, or people whose income consists entirely of superannuation or some other form of private income, be treated fairly. This Budget addresses that measure. I will get back to superannuants a little later.

The third aspect is security. This is the aspect which this Budget best addresses. As you would know, Mr Speaker, one of the complaints we had was about the uncertainty in the area of retirement incomes. People felt that many changes had been made, particularly to social security provisions. People felt uncertain about their future. For the first time, we have a long term retirement incomes policy which people can depend on for the years ahead and into the next century. It also encourages people to provide for their own retirement through superannuation. If that is not possible, it reconfirms our commitment to an adequate age pension.

The fourth aspect deemed necessary for a good retirement incomes policy was sustainability. We need a retirement incomes policy that can be applied for the long term into the next century. This means it has to be a responsible retirement incomes policy without any gimmicks, without giveaways and without a fistful of dollars. It has to be, and it is, a responsible and rational long term policy. There has been much discussion in the press and elsewhere about the benefits to pensioners contained in this Budget as well as the benefits to those currently in the work force and who will not be retiring in the future. I would like to concentrate on the benefits in this Budget for people already retired on superannuation, particularly those people on low or middle rates of superannuation income. I have had complaints in my office from constituents who allege that there is nothing in the Budget for people who are currently retired and on superannuation. That is definitely not the case. As a result of this Budget and of the April economic statement there are real benefits for people already retired on superannuation.

Four changes in those two statements will immediately benefit retired people receiving low or middle rates of superannuation. There are, firstly, the tax reductions in the 1989-90 year, which will substantially reduce the amount of tax they are paying. Secondly, there is an increase in the age pensioner rebate and a new scheme whereby the unused portion of this rebate may be transferred to the spouse. This is a particularly significant change because it provides a certain degree of splitting of the tax liability between two partners. Thirdly, there is an increase in the spouse rebate and, fourthly, an increase in the Medicare exemption levy for married couples. These four measures combined will provide a great deal of relief for retired people receiving superannuation.

All couples who are entitled to a part pension will gain at least $15 a week from these changes. Married couples with total superannuation and other non-pension income of less than $26,041 per year are entitled to a part pension. These superannuants will further benefit from increases in the rate of pension and the earlier payment of pension increases announced by the Government. The next indication increased in the age pension will be brought forward by four weeks to 15 November 1989 and indexation increases will then occur on 18 April 1990, 20 September 1990, and therefore every March and September. So superannuants entitled to a part pension will fully benefit from these increases as well as the other benefits that I have enumerated.

The Government is committed to further increases on top of indexation over time. Further initiatives which will assist most people who are currently retired and on superannuation include the annual indexation of the pension income test-free area from July 1991. This will mean an annual increase in the age rebate and the effective tax threshold for many part pensioners. For the first time this threshold will actually be indexed. From 1995 no age or service pensioner, whether on full or part rate pension, will pay any income tax. From November 1989 recipients of a pension or part pension will be able to borrow against their home-up to $40,000 excluding capitalised interest and charges. This amount will not count for the income test and therefore there will be no loss of pension. This measure will allow those eligible to take advantage of the various reverse mortgage schemes offered by financial institutions.

From January 1990 the recipient of a pension or part pension whose spouse dies will be entitled to receive special bereavement payments for the next seven fortnightly pension days. These payments will be set at the same total pension rate as the couple was receiving before the death. The surviving partner will have the option of immediately transferring to the single rate of pension and receiving the additional entitlement as a lump sum to meet pressing financial commitments. In addition, from April 1990 annuities will be made more attractive and the social security and veterans pension income tests will be amended so that that part of an annuity which is a refund of the after tax purchase price will be disregarded.

As I have indicated, there are significant benefits in this Budget and the April statement for people currently retired on superannuation. Perhaps I could just give some figures of what would be the annual increase in income of a typical superannuated couple. If, for example, the husband-and it is usually the husband-of the couple is receiving superannuation of $5,000 a year, with the tax changes coming out of this Budget that family will have an increase in income over the year of $1,001.75. For a couple on superannuation of $10,000 a year-these, of course, are all getting part pension as well-their increase in income will be $947.70. For a couple on superannuation of $15,000, their increase in income will be $799. On superannuation of $20,000, their increase in income for the 1989-90 year will be $929.10, and for a couple on superannuation of $25,000, who still are eligible for part pension, their increase in income will be $966.60. They are substantial increases in annual income and give the lie to the claims made by many people that this Budget contains nothing for people who are currently retired and on superannuation.

I should like to turn now to another aspect of the Budget but one still within the retirement income area, and that is the provision by the Department of Social Security for retired people, particularly people who are getting some sort of pension, of an information service. In our travels around the country a great deal of confusion was expressed by retired people about just what their entitlements were and to what extent extra income would affect their pensions. There was a difficulty in getting reliable information from the Department of Social Security. That was not the Department's fault; there simply were not the resources or the expertise within regional offices, or anywhere for that matter, to provide that sort of information. I know that in Adelaide, for example, there were two people in the policy section of the Department of Social Security in the city whose job it was to provide that kind of advice. They spent most of their time advising financial advisers and had very little time actually to advise clients of the Department of Social Security. As a result of this Budget extra resources, extra facilities, will be given to regional and area offices of the Department of Social Security to enable them to provide reliable and useful information to retired people about what their pension entitlements are and what their options are. I very much welcome that change.

I also mention the benefits in this Budget for older unemployed people. I am sure that, like myself, many members are visited occasionally by people in their fifties or sixties who are unemployed for some reason but who are not eligible to receive an age pension. These people are generally in a great predicament because of the difficulty they have at that age in getting employment, combined with the lack of dignity they suffer in many cases through the discrimination which is still shown by many employers against people aged 55 or more. A $10m a year package has been included in this Budget to improve income support and work opportunities for unemployed people aged 55 years and over. I welcome that measure.

The other matter I would like to mention in the few minutes I have is the significance for women of certain aspects of the retirement incomes policy. Women traditionally do not take out superannuation, for various reasons: in the past, often because they have actually not been able to-they have been actively discriminated against; and also because of the broken pattern of their working lives and the fact that often they tend to be working part time. They have not been encouraged or been able to take out superannuation and provide in any way for their retirement. Therefore they have been much more dependent than men on a social security pension.

This Budget provides for certain elements which will improve the position of women as regards superannuation. Those working as few as 10 hours a week will be able to contribute to a superannuation scheme and receive a tax deduction. Those leaving the work force may continue to contribute towards their superannuation for up to two years. This, presumably, is aimed at women on maternity leave. There will be changes in the way the maximum benefit is calculated which will help those with low or varied income levels. It will take as a benchmark $25,000 or a worker's highest salary level over three years, not just the pre-retirement level if it is above this. This advantages women, whose incomes often fall as they get older and few earn over $25,000.

I and many other members of this Government are very proud of what this Government and the Australian Labor Party have done to provide to women in the work force equal opportunity for employment and equal pay for equal work. I see this as being a kind of culmination of that policy. Not only are we getting women into the work force and seeing that they get a fair go, but we are also making sure that they are given the opportunity to provide for their retirement, so that when they finish in paid employment they have the same opportunity as men to have a comfortable and independent retirement.

I trust that other members of the Government will talk on other aspects of the Budget, but I would particularly like to commend the Government and the Treasurer for those aspects of the Budget dealing with retirement incomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, along with other members who have commented on this matter today, I congratulate you on your election to the high office of Speaker and wish you well for the period that you occupy that office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget presented two weeks ago by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gave the Australian people little hope of any relief from their now lengthy financial sufferance. When one lays aside the Hawke Government's fulsome rhetoric and examines the nuts and bolts of this latest Budget, the truth becomes starkly clear. This Budget makes absolutely no attempt to address the very worrying fundamental economic problems now afflicting our nation.

The Hawke Government in its Budget promises no relief from the very high interest rates under which we have been struggling to survive for so long. The Budget confirms that the Hawke Government has little understanding of the massive burden that high interest rates inflict upon those Australian families trying desperately to pay off a mortgage on their home. Indeed, the Westpac Banking Corporation's Consumer Banking Manager, Mr John Morris, recently said:
The Budget completely re-affirmed no downward movements this calendar year and they would be looking at the end of March before we would see any variation downwards in housing rates.

Mr Morris went on to say that the fall, when it comes, would only bring interest rates back to about 16 per cent, with last year's low of 13.5 per cent `way over the horizon'. As well as not addressing the high interest rate problem, the Budget fails to develop even a basic anti-inflationary strategy and it also fails to develop a coherent and effective strategy for increasing our productivity and exports. To compound matters, the Budget fails dismally to map out an effective strategy for reducing our total debt. It fails to encourage Australians to save and it very definitely threatens Australia with a recession.

The abject failure by this Government to tackle our appalling foreign debt problem-now $110 billion in net terms-is the principal reason why the international credit rating agency, Moody's Investors Service Inc., has downgraded Australia's credit rating from AA1 to AA2. This puts Australia's credit rating at the same level as that of Spain. This downgrading alone stands as a terrible indictment of the ineptitude in economic management displayed by the Treasurer and the Government of which he is a part. Furthermore, the huge $9.1 billion surplus so lauded by the Hawke Government and certain commentators is a monument, not to the great economic management of the Government, as it would have us believe, but to the greatest tax rip-off ever perpetrated against the Australian people.

The Grim Reaper's rapacious tax harvest of the hard earned wages and salaries of battling Australians has meant that nearly 50 per cent of taxpayers now face a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent, compared with 30 per cent in the last year of the Fraser Liberal Government. The only reputation that this Budget confirms is that the Hawke Government remains the highest taxing government since the Second World War and that, next to very expensive antique French clocks, the Treasurer's only other interest is bracket creep. Bracket creep alone will claw back 50 per cent of the 1 July tax cuts this year and almost all within the next 12 months. Indeed, if one looks at Budget Paper No. 2, one finds that the estimate of pay as you earn (PAYE) receipts for 1989-90 is $40.4 billion or $2,381.77 per capita. When one compares that with actual PAYE receipts for 1988-89, one finds that the total was $38.5 billion or $2,309.57 per capita. One can therefore see that already the Government is expecting to rip a further $1.9 billion in tax from individual Australians and a great deal of that will be through the insidious instrument of bracket creep.

This Budget contains yet further tax imposts on Australian companies. The Treasurer requires that 85 per cent of company tax is now to be payable 15 days after the income year, with the remainder payable nine months later. This policy change will adversely affect the liquidity of thousands of companies, resulting in the need to borrow further in a time of horrifically high interest rates. Furthermore, beginning on 1 December this year, companies with annual PAYE remittances exceeding $5m will be required to remit tax instalment deductions from wages and salaries twice monthly rather than monthly, which again will force companies to borrow money.

This Government's message is always the same: Australian families, the private sector and the States must pay through the nose whilst little or no restraint is shown by the Commonwealth in its own spending programs. Additionally, the need to increase production and productivity is not, as it should be, comprehensively addressed in the Budget. For two or more years we have watched and listened to the Government on its soapbox verbalising about the crucial need for micro-economic reform, yet our wharves and coastal shipping remain among the least efficient in the industrialised world. The Budget will do nothing to improve our competitiveness, nothing to bring about micro-economic reform, and nothing to free up the labour market. What it will do is ensure that inflation remains high, that interest rates remain high and that, with the Hawke Government in office, high taxes are here to stay. The Government's pathological agenda to force Australian families to the wall is reinforced under this Budget. By the end of this year a family in receipt of average weekly earnings and with two children will be about $56 worse off than when Labor came to power over six years ago. This does not take into consideration higher mortgage interest rates.

In the time remaining to me I wish to concentrate on an issue that will impact upon the balance of payments. As we all know, one of our greatest problems is that we are importing more than we are exporting. Put very simply, this fuels our foreign debt problem which in turn flows on throughout the system to affect the standard of living of each and every one of us. In his Budget Speech the Treasurer predicted that the current account deficit would blow out this year to $18.5 billion. For a number of years the Government, through the Australian Customs Service, has known the quantity and value, almost to the last cent, of every item imported into this country. This is because every item imported into Australia is logged on a Customs computer system and downloaded to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). As a result, the import figures published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics have been accurate. However, the same cannot be said for our export figures. The current system of recording exports is known as the exporter return scheme. Again, this is run by the Australian Customs Service. Under this scheme an exporter first exports his product. After the export item has physically left the country, he or she submits the paperwork containing the full information on the item exported, such as quantity and value. On receipt of this information the Customs Service promulgates it and ensures that the ABS receives it for inclusion in its statistics. The exporter return scheme has failed. It does not accurately record the quantity and value of Australian exports. I wonder how many honourable members have heard of an export reporting scheme called the EXIT scheme or, to give it its full name, the exports integration scheme?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a disaster?

—It is something that the Government has hoped will prevent a disaster. I would think that not many honourable members would have heard of this EXIT scheme. The EXIT scheme is a major new initiative to record accurately the quantity and value, down to the last cent, of every export item leaving Australia's shores. It involves the Government repealing the legislation covering the exporter return scheme and introducing new legislation to cover the EXIT scheme. The projected dates of effect for this to occur are 30 September and 1 October respectively. Despite this major new initiative-an initiative requiring new legislation and an initiative that will have an enormous effect on the accurate reporting of our exports-I can find no record of any utterances by any Government Minister on the imminent implementation of the EXIT scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: It might help honourable members if I give a brief thumbnail sketch of how the EXIT scheme will function. Essentially, EXIT means that no item will be able to leave Australia's shores without first having the quantity and value of the item or items recorded. To be fully integrated into the EXIT scheme, a company involved in exporting will need to have a computer with a modem facility to allow it to hook up to the Customs EXIT network.

The system will work like this. Exporters or their agents, after initiating all necessary arrangements for shipping their goods, will apply to Customs for pre-clearance of the consignment. Their application will contain details on the quantity and value of the goods to be exported and the application for pre-clearance will be made electronically using the EXIT network. The application information will then be checked automatically by the Customs mainframe computer against pre-set parameters and an export clearance number will be returned automatically to the sender, along with any Customs requirements, such as the need to examine the goods. When the time arrives to physically export the goods, the exporter will take them to the point of departure-say, for instance, the Melbourne docks. On the docks it will be necessary for the shipper to compile an electronic manifest which must include an export clearance number for every item that is loaded for export. The EXIT computer systems will then automatically check the validity of each export clearance number of the goods listed on the manifest. No-I repeat no-item may physically depart Australia without an export clearance number. After clearance of the manifest, all export clearance number information, plus departure details, will be forwarded electronically to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Why EXIT? Let me quote from an Australian Customs Service document that is being circulated among Australian exporters. It states:
Over the past two years Australia's exports have been the focus of Government and media attention.
Later the document goes on to say:
Several weaknesses are inherent in the current system for recording and reporting export cargo.
The reason appearing at the top of the list states:
Failure to report significant quantities of exports.

The words `significant quantities' are the words of the Australian Customs Service, the very organisation in the best position to know exactly what is going on. Just exactly how significant `significant' is, I have been unable to determine. However, given that the Government has given the green light to the implementation of the EXIT scheme, it would be a better than evens bet that it would have a fair idea of just how much in dollar terms is currently being exported without being reported and therefore not appearing in the balance of payments figures issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Customs estimate that at present approximately one-third of companies involved in exporting are currently participating in the EXIT scheme and by 1 October it hopes to have all companies plugged in. I am given to understand that there are still problems being ironed out with the EXIT scheme and these may take a little time to sort out fully. Additionally, there are also logistical delays in getting companies into the scheme.

Given that all new systems, particularly high technology systems, are susceptible to technical problems when they are introduced, and given that companies involved will take some time to become fully acquainted with the EXIT scheme, it seems reasonable to believe that the first fully comprehensive and accurate export statistics, with no significant reporting failures, will begin to be published towards the end of this year or early next year. On top of this it must be borne in mind that reputable economists, such as the Access Economics Consultancy Group, are saying that the Government's tight monetary policy is now causing a decline in spending which will cause a fall in imports. Furthermore, the same economists are also expecting that there will be rises in the volume of commodity exports sold, thus improving our trade position this year and next. Whilst I am in favour of any initiative that will provide more timely and accurate export statistics, the political advantage that I believe the Hawke Government is waiting to exploit is obvious.

I said earlier that housing interest rates are expected to fall around March next year. When this is coupled with the expected improvement in our trade position and the effect that the EXIT scheme can be expected to have on our export figures-that is, recording the significant quantities that are currently not being recorded-we see that the climate for an election becomes the warmer some time just after March next year. This House, the Australian people, and particularly the press gallery, should all be aware that as from the coming 1 October there is a very real possibility that an increasingly beleagured and cynical Hawke Government could use what are essentially falsely inflated export figures to hoodwink the nation into believing that it has at last turned the economy around. The statistical subterfuge being attempted by this Labor Government is a classic illustration of what the great British Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli once warned of. Disreali stated: `There are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies and statistics'. However, I do believe that the electorate has had enough of the Government trying to paper over hard economic realities through superficial statistical manipulation. Australians today are politically and economically more attuned and more perceptive than the Government gives them credit for. Therefore, the EXIT scheme will not save this dying Government from its own completely unlamented and long overdue exit from office. In conclusion, I seek leave to table the Australian Customs Service document concerning the EXIT scheme that I referred to earlier.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90, I want to make a couple of points about the comments of the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred). I am not quite sure what he was saying regarding the exports integration scheme, or EXIT, recording our actual export products. If he is saying that for the first time we will have accurate figures which may show that some of our estimates of exports have been wrong and that is a distortion of the truth, I am not quite sure whether his summary actually fills the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: He also said that this is the highest taxing Government and that bracket creep will take away many benefits that have been provided through the April tax benefits. It is quite amazing for a member of the previous Government, which developed tax evasion as the only growth industry during that period, to come in here and argue that our program of tax reform should be criticised. Members of the previous Government allowed all sorts of tax rorts to exist throughout the community, and the wealthy and those who were capable of manipulating their incomes avoided paying tax, thus pushing the burden onto the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, and they come in here and criticise us. We have been in office for almost seven years and we have reformed the tax system and ensured that there is a fairer tax system. People who were previously not paying their tax are now paying. With the introduction of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the withholding tax and now the tax file number system, we are ensuring that those people who were evading their responsibility in terms of contributing to the cost of running the country are now paying their tax. The reason members of the previous Government are so critical of our reforms is that for the first time most of their mates are now having to pay genuine tax.

The announced reforms of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) do not allow companies to continue to hold money that belongs to the Commonwealth in the form of collected tax revenue longer than is necessary. This Government is being criticised because it is making people forward the tax that has already been collected more quickly than they have done in the past. It seems to me that these are ridiculous arguments to be coming forward.

In relation to bracket creep, it has also been alleged that benefits provided in the form of tax cuts earlier this year will be lost, as if in some way this Government has developed bracket creep, that it was its idea, some sneaky concept that it introduced into the system. We should remember that bracket creep is a result of inflation. It is a process which has been in existence ever since governments began collecting taxation. The honourable member for Bruce would know that the coalition parties, which have been in government for some 23 of those 30 years, have had plenty of opportunity to correct what he calls `this iniquitous and terrible crime'. They have had plenty of opportunity to correct it, but they have never done so. They know that there are several ways of dealing with bracket creep. One is to look at indexation, which they have argued for, and the other is to reform the tax system from time to time or to introduce tax cuts, which is the traditional process undertaken by both sides of the House. The honourable member for Bruce knows that the April tax cuts that we introduced were more than compensation for the inflationary effects that existed from 1983 to 1988. So his argument there is also nonsense. This process has been in existence for some time.

The honourable member alleged that this Government has done nothing about borrowings. This Government has repaid more foreign debt than any government in the past. He would remember that in 1983, under the previous Government, we had borrowings in the order of 22 per cent of gross domestic product. According to the Budget Papers, that will be reduced to 13 per cent by 1990. Between 1975-76 and 1982-83, which is the period of the last conservative Government, total net overseas raisings were $4.5 billion. Between 1983-84 and 1988-89, which is the period of this Government, we have repaid in net terms a total of $1.5 billion. So the last conservative Government can be seen as a government that did nothing in terms of looking after the economy. It was the borrower. This Government has turned around and begun repaying the debt that the previous Government incurred. Due to our fiscal management and the amount of debt that we have repaid, we have already saved the community in the order of $2 billion. So I think all those arguments show that the Opposition is really clutching at straws when it attempts to criticise us on these sorts of issues.

I wanted to raise a couple of issues relating to benefits flowing from the Budget; but, more importantly, I wanted to raise one issue which relates to the increase in the postal allowance for members of parliament. A number of honourable members opposite have made public statements and attempted to accuse the Government of utilising funds to manipulate election results. That is an extraordinary argument to be putting forward. When I came into this Parliament in 1983 a member of parliament had two office staff, two telephone lines, a typewriter, a photocopying machine and some 60,000 electors to look after. It is no wonder that members were unable to relate properly to their constituents and to inform them of what was really happening. (Quorum formed) The empty bleatings of members of the Opposition about members' increased postal allowance are just that. Because they choose not to service their electorates and because they do not want constituents to realise how poor they are, they attempt to criticise the processes of this Government. As I was saying, when I came into this Parliament members of parliament had two office staff, a photocopier, a typewriter and two telephone lines. It is no wonder that members of parliament were unable to communicate properly with some 50,000 to 60,000 constituents. Members were hamstrung by an inability to utilise properly the equipment that was around.

Since this Government has been in office it has ensured that all members of parliament-honourable members on both sides of the House-have had a tremendous increase in their capacity to look after their constituents. They now have three staff members, computers, three or four telephone lines, facsimile machines and a huge range of facilities. They have also had an increase in their postal and printing facilities, which means that they now have no excuse for not servicing their electorates. Conservatives will no longer be able to hide away in their offices, not communicating with their constituents. They will have no argument or justification for not communicating with them. Because we have set out to ensure that all honourable members deal responsibly with their constituents, communicate with them and keep them informed of the things that we are doing, the Opposition has started to complain. It is a hollow argument and one that I think should be put aside.

I suppose the thing that really irks me most about this matter is the way in which some members of the Opposition have inferred that the money that is being paid for postal services in some way is coming to us as members, as if we have direct access to that cash. They know that it is simply there and available if we happen to send mail to our constituents; if we happen to use available postal services. Finally, I want to come back and remind people that when the debate is taking place on this Appropriation Bill, on this Budget, they should keep it in mind that the Budget is really being presented in two parts. There was the April statement, in which many of the benefits such as tax cuts, alterations to the payment of pensions and increases in the pension were all announced, and the Budget, which is really just wrapping up, tidying up the edges in terms of these benefits. So when people are looking at this Budget debate they should keep in mind the debate that occurred with regard to the April statement and remember that the benefits such as tax cuts, increases in the family allowance and pensions, and other such benefits which were announced then are all part of an overall economic package for which the Budget is the second part. I commend the Budget to the House and believe that the community out there will see it for what it is-a Budget of enormous benefits and an example of proper fiscal management. I am sure that the constituency out there, when it comes time to reassess the assessment it made in 1987, will do so in a way which will ensure that this party, the current Government, is going to be returned to these benches. I would not be surprised if we were back here with increased numbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the 1989 Budget brought down in this House two weeks ago fails to address the fundamental issues facing Australia, given our current economic situation. Inflation continues to run ahead of that for almost every Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) nation. Our current account deficit continues to rise; Australia's international debt of $129 billion brings home the stark reality of our dependence upon foreign money. Productivity in Australia compared to other developed countries is low. Bracket creep for individual taxpayers continues to bite. Australia's inflexible industrial relations system ensures its competitive ability is considerably reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the $9 billion surplus which the Budget indicates for the next financial year is commendable in itself, a closer examination of the background facts reveals the reason why such a surplus exists. It is largely a result of bracket creep and the accounting adjustments between the last financial year and the current financial year to date. Obviously the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in bringing down a surplus, has been trying to influence the international money markets to give the impression of economic responsibility. Only time will tell whether international financiers will continue to support such a precarious debt and current account situation.

While individual taxpayers believe they obtained some relief from the 1 July tax cuts, as always there is some sleight of hand in that proposal. In one year, half these tax cuts will be gobbled up by bracket creep and within the following 12 months Australian taxpayers will be no better off. The Treasurer has carefully targeted those vulnerable groups within the $12,500 to $17,650 income groups whose tax rates have been reduced from 29c in the dollar to 21c. Likewise, those persons on the income tax scale between $19,200 and $20,600 have had a substantial reduction in their tax rates, from 40c to 29c in the dollar. It should be said from the outset that these small tax cuts across the board offer little incentive for Australians to work harder.

Out in the electorate there is little reason for individual workers to work overtime, or even raise their productivity, because of the high marginal rates of tax. In the Budget as presented by the Treasurer, individual pay as you earn taxpayers provide 54.3 per cent of the Budget's total income, while companies contribute 11.8 per cent to the total revenue. These figures alone indicate the uneven nature of government revenues in that individuals and companies provide 65 per cent of the total Federal Government revenue. The most disturbing feature of the Budget is the forecast for inflation in the current financial year of 7 1/2 per cent. As all Australians will be fully aware, last year's inflation rate of 7 per cent, after a Budget estimate of 4 1/2 per cent, was an economic disaster for those in low income groups and those on fixed incomes. It also impacted severely on those export industries trying to increase Australia's competitive position with other trading nations in the Western world.

A comparison with inflation rates in other countries makes our very uncompetitive and deteriorating position all too clear. I pause to reflect on the inflation rates in other OECD countries as at June 1989: United States of America, 5 per cent; Japan, 1 1/2 per cent; Canada, 4 1/4 per cent; four major OECD countries in Europe, 4 1/4 per cent; and the United Kingdom, 6 1/4 per cent. Our precarious position is all the more disturbing when one looks at the current estimates for inflation over the next six months of 7 1/2 per cent. There has been no allowance made for industrial relations catastrophes such as the current pilots strike, or the possibility of a major wages breakout which could blow these predictions completely off target.

I now wish to move to the Budget Papers and the basis of Treasury's major assumptions in putting the Budget together for the current year. In passing I would like to compliment Treasury officials on the outstanding job they have done in putting the Budget Papers together, in making the figures understandable and presenting a clear and cogent picture of the Australian economy and the Government's Forward Estimates. The basic assumptions upon which the Budget is predicated do not stand up to a clinical assessment. The first assumption is that growth will be down in the OECD and Asian countries from 5 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent in 1989-90. Commentators around the world are very concerned about the impact of a soft or hard landing in the United States economy and its problems with inflation. Both the internal and external deficits run up by the Reagan Administration could impact severely on this assessment.

The next major assumption is that Australia's trading partners will have an inflation rate of 4 1/2 per cent and, as I indicated earlier, this compares unfavourably with Australia's projected inflation rate of 7 1/2 per cent. The third basic assumption by the Treasurer is that growth in world trade will be down from 8 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent in the forecast year of 1989-90. At a time when commodity prices have enjoyed buoyant levels this could have a major effect on our export revenue which in turn would not help our current account deficit problem. The fourth assumption is that overseas nominal interest rates will remain at 1989-90 levels, and whilst they remain substantially below rates in Australia this will have the effect of ensuring a flow of funds to Australia's higher interest rate regime. The fifth assumption is that monetary policy will remain tight, with high interest rates being maintained in the short term. The consequent effect will be that the productive elements of the Australian economy will continue to suffer under the 20 to 21 per cent interest rates.

The next major assumption is that the exchange rate will remain at 58 on the trade weighted index and that the American dollar will be worth 75c Australian. On this assumption the exchange rate will do nothing to help our exporters and, more likely, will further encourage imports. Moreover, the continued high interest rate policy of the Treasurer will prop up the exchange rate to curtail further the ability of our exporters to compete. The next assumption is that the Industrial Relations Commission will be able to control wages, bringing about two instalments of 3 per cent over the next 12 months. Most commentators would agree that the accord has failed and that the likelihood of a wages breakout is imminent. The trade union movement is struggling desperately to maintain the system despite the fact that the union movement enjoys only 32 per cent membership of the total work force. Whilst the furphy of union restructuring in minimum award rates represents the major hurdle facing the union movement at present, the flexibility of our labour market has been further hampered by industrial arrangements organised under our present centralised system.

Perhaps one of the few aspects of the Budget which the Opposition agrees with is a recognition of the role of superannuation in providing capital in the longer term for all Australians. The Treasurer has made an assumption that there will be a build-up in capital through superannuation arrangements. In his judgment, these benefits will become operative in 1992-when the coalition will be in government. His forethought is commendable.

Perhaps the key issue currently facing all Australians is why interest rates are so high. Hardworking Australians find it difficult to understand why interest rates are running at record levels when the Treasurer continues to insist that the economy is under control. Yet interest rates for bank overdrafts remain between 19 and 20 per cent and home loan mortgage rates are running at between 17 and 18 per cent. It would appear to them that there is plenty of credit available, yet for some reason interest rates have been manipulated to suit the policy objectives of this Government, with quite devastating effects on individuals with large overdrafts or house mortgages.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are right.

—They are absolutely right. This raises the issue of credit availability and the money supply. Historically, this has been a complicated question, and with a deregulated market the various measures of money supply have become increasingly difficult to determine with any accuracy. In Australia the matter has been addressed by Mr Ian McFarlane, head of research for the Reserve Bank of Australia. In a paper delivered in April 1989 he makes the comment that there are measurement difficulties in the M1 and M3 money supply criteria. He observes that from 1983 to 1988, using these two measures, money supply increased at an annual rate of 12.5 per cent. He also observes that, from statistical information available, bank credit expanded by 23.8 per cent over the same period while other institutional forms of credit expanded by 21.6 per cent annually. Mr McFarlane also states that, in his view, worldwide inflation began spiralling significantly during the 1970s. Throughout this period fast monetary growth was coupled with low interest rates. Over the last five years, however, real and nominal interest rates have been much higher than they were during the 1970s. He poses this question, which concerns every elector throughout Australia: Why is there so much credit available, and how is it affecting the national economy? His view is that it is the natural result of two decades of high inflation and the interaction between inflation and the tax system. In such a high inflationary environment there are major advantages of increased debt over equity. As we have all seen from a cursory glance at the stock market and other forms of business investment, entrepreneurs have used highly geared companies to create wealth for themselves and their shareholders via this medium.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Kingdom provides a stark example of the problems of extended money supply. In the Wall Street Journal of March 1989, Mr Congdon, a London economics adviser, draws attention to the Thatcher Government's strict control of the money supply between 1979 and 1986, during which time it gained international credibility in controlling inflation. During this six-year period the money supply was held at an average growth rate of 10 per cent. In line with this policy, the constant rate of inflation was 5 per cent. However, from mid-1985 to mid-1989 the money supply doubled to 20 per cent per annum. In 1985 the United Kingdom experienced a surplus balance of payments of one per cent of gross domestic product, yet by 1988 this surplus had become a deficit of 3.5 per cent of GDP. Mr Congdon makes the policy observation:
Sustained money control is an essential condition for a reduction in inflation.

Recent economic policy in Britain has therefore one simple message for other countries: sustained monetary control is an essential condition for sustained reduction in inflation. It is a message that the Treasurer could well take on board.

I refer the House to an article by Max Newton in the Australian today. He drew attention to the problems in America with the blow-out in the money supply from the years 1971 to 1981 while inflation remained very high. From 1981 to 1989 there was a cut in the money supply because of a change of policy by the United States Treasury and the inflation factor fell. We therefore see two countries where the attitude towards money supply has been effective and has had a major effect on the inflationary factor.

The credibility of the 1989 Budget has been severely reduced. There have been two important reports, one as recently as this morning. We saw, firstly, the Reserve Bank's very carefully worded statement about Australia's present economic situation and, secondly, the downgrading this afternoon of Australia's international credit rating from AA1 to AA2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. earlier. Both reports reflect the lack of credibility in the Budget and the way in which the economy is being managed by the Treasurer and the Government.

The two reports are complementary in their indictment of the current financial problems facing Australia and the future build-up of debt which is a direct result of the Treasurer's lax monetary and fiscal approach. Moody's emphasised the large and continuing current account deficit and indicated that Australia's debt servicing ratio has fallen out of line with other AA1 rated countries since the last downgrade in September 1986. The factors which Moody's consider to be crucial to this rating action include the following: the Government's inability to control excessive demand growth; insufficient progress in generating sufficient exporting capacity and restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains; and the continued slow pace of structural adjustment which, in its view, makes Australia ill positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign currency debt. In simple words, Moody's are advising overseas creditors that Australia is not a good risk because of its continued current account deficit problems and mounting national debt.

The Reserve Bank makes crystal clear its own view of the policy framework upon which the Government is operating and the attendant risks ahead. Its report is a very carefully worded document and supports the Opposition's claims that the economy is overheated, inflation is too high, monetary policy is only one mechanism to control the economy, interest rates are a problem, and the current account deficit is too high. I will quote from a section of that carefully worded report, which has been mentioned in the Parliament today, indicating that domestic spending has been too great and the current account deficit is too big. The report states:

Private spending grew much more rapidly in 1988-89than had been expected. This led to a severe pressure on resources in some parts of the economy, concern at the emergence of stronger inflationary pressures, and a further deterioration in the current account deficit. Though Australia's economic growth in that year was high, it was more than accounted for by domestic demand; net exports fell.

The Treasurer himself in his Budget Speech agreed with that proposition when he said that national spending increased by 8 per cent. However, national production increased by only 4 per cent, and the gap was our import bill. The Reserve Bank also indicates the bad effects of high interest rates on productive investments. It states:

On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types. Nevertheless, monetary policy has an essential role in supporting structural reform.

The Reserve Bank makes the comment that Australia needs to be more competitive and to export more goods and services. We need to create a savings environment and borrow less from abroad. I quote again:

Australia needs a major shift of resources into the traded goods sector to stimulate increased exports and, more importantly, to replace imports. This cannot be achieved if domestic demand is growing faster than productive capacity; but simply slowing demand is not enough either. There is also a need for greater productive capacity, improved productivity and a better overall price performance, at least as good as our competitors. We need also, if possible, to fund a greater proportion of our investment from our own resources and not by borrowing abroad; in other words, more savings, less consumption.
It goes on with this very critical comment:
Restructuring is more difficult, even impossible, in a high inflation environment which destroys competitiveness and discourages savings.

The coalition wishes to bring about when it is in government a more productive culture, an industrial relations environment where management and the work force can bring about their own agreements and remove the third party arrangements of the Industrial Relations Commission. When in government the coalition will control inflation, introduce a two-tier tax system and reduce the incidence of bracket creep on individual Australians. It will control the money supply, reduce interest rates and reduce the overseas debt commitment. It will reduce the current account deficit and make sure that Australia exports more and imports less. Under a coalition government the exchange rate will be such as to encourage exporters. It will provide incentive for operators to export goods and services on behalf of all Australians. A coalition government will cut government expenditure and the level of tax on individuals and companies so that they will work harder, take risks and be more efficient and competitive. When it comes to government the coalition will address all those issues and put Australia back on the road to economic prosperity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), on one thing and that is that we cannot take the Australian public for mugs. It pointed out that we faced the Great Depression because of low productivity and the national debt. In other words, governments and private enterprise were unable to borrow the money to keep the country going. The article said that the national debt was only #5 per person in 1928-29.

Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.

. . . CPI should be running at 4 1/2 per cent by the end of the financial year.
He continued:

He said that the balance of payments would be halved from its peak of just three years ago. He predicted that the balance of payments deficit would be about $9 billion. It is up to over $18 billion. Our inflation trend is almost double what the Treasurer said it would be. Our interest rates are 18 to 22 or 23 per cent. Can any country afford to operate under conditions like these? Again I come back to the fact that we, the members of this House and of the Senate, who have the responsibility to run the affairs of the nation are not measuring up to the expectations of the average decent Australian. We have seen this deterioration as the years have gone on and we will continue to see it while we follow policies such as those the Government currently is adopting.

What would have happened to this country if in the past six or seven years we had not had very favourable seasons? On 31 May this year all honourable members will recall the tabling of a report entitled Going for Gold which was the first report into this very subject by the aforementioned Committee of this Parliament. It is interesting at this time just to reflect on the work that committees of this place perform and the results that can be obtained.

In the course of today's proceedings in the House for the election of the new Speaker mention was made of the contribution of the honourable gentleman in his former capacity as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure and a report that was done-that Expenditure Committee was the forerunner of this Committee-called In a Home or at Home: Accommodation and Home Care for the Aged-A Follow-up Report. It subsequently led to the development of the Government's home and community care program. I think that again indicates the role that committees can play in the development of policy and the enactment of policy in Australia through this Parliament. Exactly the same thing can be said about this report Going for Gold. Whilst I am not claiming that everything that was contained in this report has been adopted by the Government, certainly the most important recommendations have been involved in preparing the report hope that some of the other recommendations will be embraced by the Government in time.

One of the things that we concluded in this report was in fact that the Forward Estimates that I mentioned just a moment ago were totally unacceptable. The Committee was unanimous. Those people from the other side and members of the Government were unanimous in the view that the allocations for sport in this country as proposed in the Forward Estimates were totally unacceptable. The result of that has been quite staggering. There will be an enormous boost for sport over the next four years totalling some $230m. Those revised estimates now read as follows: For 1988-89, $27.6m was spent; 1989-90, $42.9m; 1990-91, $54.7m; 1991-92, $58.4m and 1992-93, $63.6m. (Quorum formed)

As I was saying, the Forward Estimates clearly demonstrate the commitment of this Government to sport and show quite clearly the massive increases in funding that will go towards Australian sport over the next five years. I was also saying that this has largely been as a result of pressure brought to bear by Senator Richardson and, as I understand it, a great deal of support that was lent to him in his deliberations at the Expenditure Review Committee by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Therefore on behalf of all those people who do enjoy sport in this country and who want to see it get a fair go I congratulate both of those gentlemen and, of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), whose interest in sport is legendary, on the work that they did on behalf of the people of Australia in respect of the allocation of the funds. But how are those funds to be spent?

I think it is important that we take a moment of the House's time just to go into that because it does show up some very interesting statistics. For example the Australian Sports Commission-a creature which in fact grew out of the Opposition when it was in government but which has prospered under this Government-is now going to receive $42.9m in 1989-90 compared with $27.5m in 1988-89. This is a quite incredible increase in funding. It will be offset to some extent by a reduction in staff numbers, but there will be an injection of funds into a number of the residential programs.

Elite sports are also the subject of special consideration by the Government in this package which the Minister released over a week ago. The Australian Sports Kit was launched with that package, and ushered in a new era for elite sports in this country. Elite sports can look forward to an additional $27m to be allocated to 25 sports which are currently under consideration for inclusion in the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS), controlled by the Australian Sports Commission. Those honourable members who participated in the inquiry which led to the publication of the report entitled Going for Gold will recall that evidence suggested that the Commonwealth Government's responsibility for funding 108-plus sports in this country was quite nonsensical. In fact, the amount of money needed to fund the elite sports men and women involved in those 108 sports is also quite nonsensical. We recommended that between 17 and 25 sports receive special assistance from the Government in order to develop elite talent in this country. What was envisaged was that the Australian Sports Commission, through the Institute, would foster those particular sports and moneys would be allocated accordingly. I am pleased to see that the thrust of the report has been picked up by Senator Richardson in the package that he has announced. He has suggested that up to 25 sports be funded.

One matter that members of our Committee would find heartening is accountability. Audited assessments will be made of those sports and how the money is to be spent. That goes to the heart of accountability and will improve the credibility of those sports because, if they do not perform and succeed, they cannot expect to get continued Government assistance. We have allocated an extra $51.7m over the next four years to help elite athletes. A new elite athletes assistance scheme will provide direct grants of between $2,000 and $10,000 for up to 315 of our top athletes. In addition, the sports talent encouragement plan is to be revitalised-that is, the old STEP program-to provide encouragement grants of between $1,000 and $2,000 to 3,000 potential elite athletes.

It is very pleasing to see this new elite scheme that will offer up to $10,000 to our elite athletes. The life that they lead, the effort that they put into their sport and the financial drain on them are absolutely incredible. Our Committee, in order to get evidence for its report, listened to hardship stories told by elite athletes such as Duncan Armstrong, Debbie Flintoff-King and others. These stories go to the heart of the problems of these people. It is very interesting that in this country people are quite willing to support struggling artists or people involved in cultural pursuits. They say that it is appropriate to throw money at those people-and rightly so-because they contribute to our society. By the same token, one should be prepared to fund the training of our elite athletes so that they can participate in a Commonwealth or Olympic Games, represent their country and go for gold. Yet people say, `Perhaps we don't really have to look after them; they will just get by'.

Elite athletes have to struggle to train and there are certain requirements in terms of training routines, food supplements and all the rest of it. If one talks to some of the athletes-I refer particularly to the cycling fraternity in Adelaide and Charlie Walsh-one will hear the real story. These people do not have the opportunity to undertake full time employment. If they are in receipt of some form of grant from either the Commonwealth or State governments there are limitations on getting additional assistance. They cannot apply for the unemployment benefit, for example. So it is appropriate that the Government has seen fit, in its sports package announced by the Minister, to look after the needs of those people.

It is pleasing that an Athlete Advisory Service has been established. An amount of $300,000 over each of the next four years will be made available to assist our elite athletes in seeking employment and education. That is an extremely important point. With regard to that issue, I think it is about time that people in the community recognised that Government has done its part to assist sports men and women by implementing this package, and it is about time that the private sector did something along those lines. Our Committee is at present investigating the very difficult and vexed question of sports sponsorship by tobacco companies and breweries, which presently amounts to $50m annually. Unfortunately, if that amount is eliminated there does not seem to be anyone in corporate Australia who will come forward to look after our elite sports men and women or, indeed, sporting teams that have done well. I refer continually to one example which I find absolutely staggering. The Australian women's hockey team won gold in Seoul. Within two weeks of returning home their sponsor, Esanda Finance Corporation Ltd, decided that the team no longer met its corporate requirements and it gave the team the flick. Fortunately, Telecom Australia offered a much healthier sponsorship which is very good for the sport. This example shows the problems that are faced even by our champions. Debbie Flintoff-King, who won a gold medal in a hurdles event, was also in difficult circumstances. Her husband worked and also trained swimmers after work. He did all sorts of things to raise money so that his wife could continue in athletics-her chosen field of excellence. Of course, she succeeded; but it was a long time before anyone came along and said, `You've done well, so we'll give you something for your trouble'. This Government has made some advances in that area.

The Government has also done something about assistance for travel for elite athletes. We have increased the amount of subsidy available for travel from 10 to 20 per cent of travel costs to over 40 per cent. That must also be welcomed. It is time that the private sector did its bit. I congratulate, as I have done in the past, Australian Airlines for taking that initiative. It has employed four of Australia's elite athletes. It has given them the opportunity to learn a skill and earn a wage, and at the same time it has given them the opportunity to train and to travel overseas to compete in top competitions, which our athletes desperately need to do in order to succeed. Of course, it will also give them time to compete in Commonwealth and Olympic Games in the future. Those athletes will have a future after sport. I think that is appropriate. More people in the broad community sector should be looking at that aspect. For example, I heard the other day that Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd, which has sponsored country rugby league in New South Wales ever since Adam ran around in a No. 7 jumper, has decided this year to give it away. One must ask why it has done so. Why are some private enterprises not already taking advantage of the tax incentives offered through the Australian Sports Aid Foundation? Is there a need to revamp that scheme? Our Committee made some recommendations on that point, which I hope the Government will look at in the not too distant future.

I have given an indication of the amount of money that will be allocated to some of these programs for elite athletes and elite sports men and women. One of the other pleasing aspects of the Government's announcements on sport in the Budget related to coaches. We understand, from looking at the figures that are contained in the Australian Sports Kit, that about $15.6m will be provided over the next four years for coaching. I think that is most appropriate. One cannot develop talent, identify talent or promote it unless one has properly trained coaches. The only way that one can attract them is to give them some incentive. We found that some coaches were not getting reasonable remuneration for the hours that they put in and the devotion that they offered their sport. Our Committee recommended that, where a national coach is not the AIS head coach, the Commonwealth accept responsibility for funding that position. That has also been accepted by the Minister and funding has been made available.

Perhaps the most significant and personally satisfying part of the package announced by Minister Richardson related to Aussie Sports. Aussie Sports has been developed to modify the rules of some of the more important sports in our program to make them more appropriate for children. We have seen a massive increase, a doubling to $1.41m, in the forthcoming budget for Aussie Sports. Over the next four years $5.8m will be made available. To top that off, the Government has also committed some money for a national sports fund program, youth sports. Several thousand young people from high schools will be trained in basic activities along the lines of the model in Western Australia. I commend the Western Australian Government for its particular activities in that regard. Young people will be taken after school and trained in basic sporting activities to develop their skills, confidence and ability to compete.

All in all, the package that is before us for consideration as part of this Budget for sport is welcomed by the sporting community, and by those members of this House who have an ongoing and abiding interest in sport, the promotion of sport in Australia, healthier life-styles, encouragement of competition and improved living standards for our children and for those involved in sport. The Minister, Senator Richardson, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are to be congratulated for their support. I suggest that honourable members should keep tabs on this for the future because it will provide major benefits for this country.
