SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the indulgence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the pretence that he has as much time as he likes to secure his place in history by desperately clinging on to power, he runs the grave risk of taking the economy of Australia down with him. The political virtues of this Budget from the point of view of the Australian Labor Party are clear enough for all to see. Every interest group or section of voters has something there to appease it. No-one is greatly offended by the obvious new imposts-or so the Prime Minister's wish list leads him to believe. But, despite these apparent virtues, Labor cannot cover up the reality of its flawed judgment in almost every area of its stewardship of economic policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has one credit to its name: the Budget surplus, albeit a tax driven surplus. It has latterly presented budgetary policy as the only area of policy for which the Government accepts responsibility. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) presents the largely spurious argument that the Budget surplus will solve such economic problems as high interest rates, high inflation and the current account deficit. To demonstrate what a silly argument that is, I remind honourable members of the economic situation as it prevails in the United States. It has a large Budget deficit and a diminishing but large balance of payments problem. However, interest rates and inflation in that country are a fraction of those in Australia. The reason for our failure in those two key areas is the Government's failed monetary policy. Contrary to the protestations of honourable members opposite, high interest rates are not an indication of so-called tough monetary policy or brave, disciplined economic policy to counter the external imposts on the economy. Interest rates as high as those in Australia at the moment are confirmation of failed monetary policy. The inevitable fall-if it is not a collapse-of interest rates from their present levels will not be an indication of the Government's success in overcoming difficulty; it will be the signpost of failure accompanied as it will be, by a rapidly declining demand for credit as the economy moves into an unnecessary recession.

For too long the Government maintained a loose monetary policy to avoid making the tough decisions which will now be forced on it or, if Labor continues its responsibility, will be forced on the next Government. Inflation has been maintained in Australia at ridiculously high levels. These policy failures have led directly to the increases in Australia's foreign debt to over $108 billion net in just a few short years of Labor rule. This cannot be blamed on the private sector. The private sector's share of gross foreign debt has remained fairly constant throughout recent economic history. The private sector is simply reacting to the economic incentives provided by the Government's policies.

All debt is made to look attractive by the Government's taxation policies by a comparatively high inflation rate and by artificially high economic growth. Foreign debt is made to look attractive by high domestic interest rates. None of these factors is the fault of the private sector, which is now struggling under the weight of interest rates which are well over 20 per cent for most borrowers. For some reason, honourable members opposite seem to envisage wicked businessmen sitting down and deciding to go heavily into debt just to deprive Labor of nice sounding economic statistics. Debt decisions are made on the basis of many factors and of those, Government taxation policy, inflation levels, general economic conditions and interest rates either flow from, or are all closely related to, government policies. The combination of all these factors in Australia under the Labor Government has mandated the rise of corporate and private debt. Nor are high interest rates the fault of the banks, which are desperately trying to compete for diminishing funds. When normal deposits are earning 17 per cent and more, is it surprising that home loan interest rates are at the same level and above? There is nothing in these high interest rates for banks, which earn profits on the spread between the interest paid for deposits and the interest charged for loans. Those spreads are not high at present.

The utter disgrace of the dishonest campaign by certain Labor Party members opposite to blame the banks for the failings of their own Government has demeaned themselves, this chamber and those unfortunate people who they egged on in their tirades against the banks. The way they focused their campaign on particular individuals whose only crime was to tell the truth as they saw it is reminiscent of the worst propaganda efforts of governments in countries less free than our own.

Under the present Treasurer, the Budget Speech itself has become more than ever an exercise in propaganda. A cosy chat with television viewers about the economy, which no longer informs the listener about departmental allocations that have to be searched for in the Budget Papers, and hides more than it discloses, has become the Treasurer's forte. This year he spent nearly as much time criticising the Opposition and indulging in insecure self-justification as he did outlining solutions to the very grave problems facing this country.

I now turn to some of the detail of the Budget. There are three matters in particular which I want to raise if time is available to me. The first is the taxation measures in the Budget, which represent an enormous drain on businesses and individuals. Then comes the nature of the Budget surplus and the Treasurer's false claim to have reduced the size of government. Finally, there is the hypocrisy of the Government's approach to indexation.

It is impossible to assess the record of the Hawke Labor Government without looking at its record in the area of taxation. New, complex and increasingly onerous taxation laws have been the hallmark of legislation deriving from successive Budgets for the past six or seven years. This Budget continues that tradition. In 1989-90, the Treasurer will impose a greater burden on corporate businesses. Last year the brunt of his assault was borne by superannuants. In earlier years investors, employers and pensioners have all suffered. Throughout this time, the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer has been subjected to the increasingly onerous collection efforts of the Australian Taxation Office of tax levied on income at very high marginal rates. Based on the figures in this Budget, the boom in government revenue over Labor's time in office will see total tax revenue up by a massive 123 per cent; personal taxation will also be up by 123 per cent, company tax will be up by 143 per cent, and indirect taxes will be up by a massive 200 per cent. The rapid rises in revenue from indirect taxes are often characterised as the Treasurer's consumption tax by stealth. What could be more appropriate.

The changes to corporate taxation payments and unpaid corporate collection of pay-as-you-earn tax for the Government represent another example of the way that this Government does not understand or care how business operates. Last year the Government brought forward the collection of revenue with its changes to the taxation of superannuation. This year it will attempt by the same sort of trick to bring forward 85 per cent of the company tax payments which would otherwise have been due some months later. It is estimated that this will bring forward $885m in the 1989-90 financial year, $150m in the following year, and estimated continuing so-called savings of $330m in interest on Commonwealth Government short term debt. This money does not come from thin air. Most of the longer term revenue gains will come from the pockets of shareholders in Australian companies. The new arrangements will be both costly and difficult to adhere to.

The Government's rationale for this change is entirely spurious. Company revenue is not like a taxpayer's salary and should not be treated in the same way. Payments to companies often are not regular. They can fluctuate significantly with economic conditions and the uncertainty of receiving and fulfilling contracts. Lists of trading creditors are often long. But the Government now expects companies to pay 85 per cent of their so-called notional tax, which is calculated on the basis of the previous year's income, within 15 days of the end of their accounting year. At that stage the companies will still be collecting the income which they are expected to pay tax on and much of that income will still be outstanding. Again, at that stage, companies will only have a general idea of their full year's profits and will not be in any position to claim for variation of the 85 per cent rule to be imposed.

The early payment will impact directly on the cash flow position of all companies. It will undermine an ability to plan for the future. It will have a particularly harsh impact on companies which are just setting up and have little idea about how likely the income from the early years' operations is to change. It will hit a declining company so hard that some will not be able to survive. This new impost will come in a year when cash flow has already been depleted by ruinously high interest rates and declining sales as the Treasurer tries to reduce economic demand. Any so-called saving by the Government on its own interest bill will be offset by the necessity for companies to borrow at very high interest rates to meet their earlier tax obligations.

The cumulative effects of this change and other government policies on Australian businesses should not be underestimated. On top of this silly new imposition the Government adds insult to injury by suggesting that companies effectively receive some sort of interest-free loan from the Government. What absolute garbage! The Government does not view the overpayment of tax to the Commonwealth, which is later refunded, as an interest-free loan to the Government by taxpayers. If it does, it is quite willing to take advantage of the situation and rip off those taxpayers by denying them interest on those funds.

The essential problem with the Treasurer's argument is that company tax is not levied on income but on profits and is affected by a range of non-cash and other considerations such as depreciation. Companies do not declare their annual profits until they have completed the detailed accounting for the year and have a clear idea of what their profits actually are. Usually, final accounts are subjected also to lengthy audit. Shareholders do not get their interim dividends or their reports of profits until well into the next financial year, and final dividends come later still.

What morality dictates that the Government get in for its chop before shareholders? What precedent is there for that? Under this proposal the shareholders of companies will have to lose out once again so that the Treasurer can con people into believing that his mildly expansionary Budget involves some expenditure restraint, while a still larger surplus of money is taken from the taxpayers of Australia.

The other taxation change in the Budget which affects companies is the doubling of the number of times each year that larger companies will have to pay instalments of pay-as-you-earn tax on behalf of their employees. This will also have effects on the cash flow of the companies concerned and will increase the administrative and cost burdens imposed by the taxation system. The Government is bringing forward $550m in revenue through this ruse. It is a counterproductive change which is in keeping with the Treasurer's efforts to squeeze every last drop he can out of taxpayers.

The Budget surplus is the Treasurer's greatest pride. Indeed, it is good that the Federal Government is no longer mortgaging the future by running up debts to pay for current consumption. However, the honourable member for Blaxland, the Treasurer, has spoiled his good work by claiming that the Budget surplus is what it quite clearly cannot be. Public sector savings are not the same as, or as desirable as, those of private individuals who must pay for the surplus through their taxes. The surplus is not a replacement for tax reform which will remove disincentives to save. The money saved by government-to use the jargon of the Treasurer-is money not available for those who earned it to save, to invest, or, for that matter, to spend. If the surplus is used to pay off government debt, as the Treasurer claims, it is not really a saving; it is meeting an obligation earlier than otherwise possible. The only real saving is the money not spent in later years on interest repayments.

The Prime Minister has made it clear that he sees the surplus as a treasure chest, available to dig out of the ground on a rainy day in case the Australian Labor Party needs more tax cuts to buy a few more votes. The Government has slowed the rate of growth of government spending from the highs which it reached in its early years in office and which, by 1986, had brought Australia to the very brink of economic disaster. However, the growth in taxation has contributed most to generating the Budget surplus. This year the taxation measures that I have already referred to will account for $1,765m of the Budget surplus. On top of that the Government deferred revenue from asset sales last year to boost further the surplus in the current year, by just over $1 billion. These referrals were made possible by larger than forecast revenue from imposts such as sales tax which, incidentally, were predicted by many commentators at this time last year.

A large increase in revenue from the fringe benefits tax is another bonus from the hidden wages explosion which the Government will take its share of. Cuts in government expenditure have, in large part, come from payments to the States and to other levels of government. Few programs have been axed although, admittedly, some have been made more efficient. Despite the mirage of stringency over the Government's spending programs, the Treasury is predicting further growth in public sector demand greater than that of last year. The surplus is a good thing and will remain so until government debt has been repaid, but we should not make too much of it.

The final point that I want to raise is the inconsistent attitude of the Treasurer when it comes to indexation. He has argued with some force that there is a danger that universal indexation can institutionalise inflation and cause major distortions in the economy. That is the standard Treasury argument. However, it bears little relevance to the proposals for inflation adjustment that are being considered by the Opposition. The type of indexation which is most damaging to the economy and to efforts to reduce inflation is precisely that which has for so long been the favourite of the Labor Party. Wage indexation is foremost amongst these examples of economic folly.

Under the stewardship of the honourable member for Blaxland the Government has indexed every revenue measure possible so as to increase government revenue in line with inflation. Similarly, Labor has claimed it as virtuous to index government benefits and pensions which are largely spent on consumption. The effect of Labor's indexation of everything which is convenient to it has been to provide an incentive for the Government to continue its inflationary policies. Taxation of real rather than nominal interest gains would not only provide an incentive for individuals to save but also remove an incentive for government to inflate. The coalition's proposal is not to introduce distortions but to reduce the distortions from years of inflation. Similarly, a properly grandfathered proposal to allow tax deductions for the real component of interest payments on debt need not introduce undue distortions.

The Treasurer's argument is fine if the Government is serious about reducing inflation and if the Government had always eschewed inflation. However, this Government has done nothing to tackle inflation. It institutionalises it by promising to index whatever will increase government revenue and whatever will neutralise people's concerns about inflation. All of these measures are themselves inflationary in their economic effects. The proposals that the coalition is now considering are not.

Honourable members opposite have talked about difficult times and trying circumstances. These have been the good times. Throughout the life of the Hawke Labor Government the world has gone through a long economic boom which has produced an increased demand for raw materials and processed goods, increased the value of capital and fixed assets, and produced greater prosperity throughout the Western world. Sadly, Australia has missed the opportunities of this boom. The Labor Party might be marching towards the light on the hill, but that hill always turns out to be a false crest on the mountain which hides a steep incline before the march upwards can be renewed.

The Government has indulged itself in the Weimar solution to Australia's economic problems. It has tried to inflate its way out of massive debt producing a massive increase in revenue, penalising those who are prudent creditors and, ultimately, threatening to cripple the economy. If we are to avoid the same fate as the Weimar Republic the Government has placed us in the position where some type of recession is almost essential--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the House tonight on the threat to our pharmacists, who are the backbone of our pharmaceutical benefits scheme and who for years have actually given free service to our community in terms of advice. They have saved the health system millions of dollars with their free advice. What thanks do they get? They get a government which is trying to run them out of business, and doing a very good job of it. It is at Government prompting that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal has cut services to pharmacists by 23 per cent. It cut them last year by 12 per cent, so that is 23 per cent on top of 12 per cent.
—Have you read the report?

—Unlike the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, I have read the report. I wish I could say the same for him. Just to notate the cuts briefly: firstly, there is to be a reduction in the professional fee from $4.55 to $3.50-a $1.05 cut, or 26 per cent effectively, bearing in mind that there was a 12 per cent cut last year. On top of that, of course, there is to be no mark-up on drugs dispensed by the pharmacist. Currently the mark-up is 25 per cent. Let me just explain what is going on here, because there is an extra problem on top of this which the Tribunal clearly has not addressed. The wholesalers actually impose a surcharge, currently about 5.6 per cent, on the cost of the goods, which is borne by the pharmacists. So if a pharmacist dispenses a $60 item at present, he pays a surcharge of some $3.64. That means, in fact, that he gets $3.50 back from the Government: he actually pays 14c to dispense that item. No tribunal in its right mind could have planned that.

SPEECH.PARA: No mark-up, of course, means no stocks. It means that delays for consumers-and these are sick consumers we are talking about-may be prolonged and it may cause them some inconvenience. What other business in Australia has no mark-up on its goods? How can the Tribunal make such an amazing miscalculation? The answer to that is, in fact, quite simple. It was very largely calculated on a data base to which only 0.3 per cent of the pharmacists in Australia responded.

What will happen as a result of this Remuneration Tribunal decision is that a number of pharmacies will close. They will have no choice. They will be run out of business. We are talking conservatively about 1,500 of the 5,600 pharmacies in Australia. One may say that will not make any difference, that market forces will prevail, et cetera. The truth is, of course, that some of those pharmacies will be in isolated areas. It may be the only pharmacy in a country town. It may be the only pharmacy that is accessible to a group of pensioners. There certainly will be a reduction in the number of pharmacies offering after hours services, which by their very nature are expensive. When one is in a situation where one's costs are threatened, as they are now by this Government-inspired decision, then the first thing that is cut back is the expensive part of the operation. After hours services will become a luxury that none of us will be able to have access to in the future.

On top of that there are other aspects of this decision which are absolutely amazing. There is no encouragement whatsoever for professional training. Even though the Government got it wrong in terms of the details of its attempt to provide training for general practitioners, at least it did have the sense to try to encourage professional training to improve the standard of GPs. It has done nothing at all to encourage the same amongst pharmacists. There should be a recognition of training and expertise. The Government should make sure that they receive an appropriate remuneration because they will then be able to give better quality advice, which in turn will mean that fewer people will need to go to their physician, whose fees are more expensive both to the community at large and in particular to the Government.

What has happened is that, rather than there not being any encouragement, there is a positive discouragement. When a pharmacist is pressed financially he tries to increase his turnover. If he increases his turnover he does not have time to sit down and chat to his patients and explain to them about the interaction of drugs, when they should take them, whether they should take them with meals, whether they should mix them with alcohol, et cetera. What happens is that the service gets faster and therefore, unfortunately, gets worse. The pharmacists have no choice in this matter.

The public of Australia is recognising this. I personally have received almost 200,000 signatures from members of the public complaining about this attack on the pharmacists. I think this is a record number of signatures for a single issue such as this from a single member of this House. The pharmacists, I should point out, have actually been penalised entirely inappropriately because, amongst all the groups in our society, they have very clearly increased their productivity. With most groups, if they increase their productivity they get paid more. This Government believes that when somebody increases his productivity he must have been earning too much to start off with, therefore it cuts back his income. So although the pharmacists' productivity has markedly increased, quite clearly they have been singled out.

There are two groups which have been singled out at present. We discussed the airline pilots earlier today. Quite clearly, this Government is attacking all employee groups which do not fit in with mainstream trade unionism. Neither the pilots nor the pharmacists are mainstream trade unionists in the sense in which the Government recognises this word. I understand that, according to the Tribunal handout, it actually proposes a further inquiry into the structure of pharmacy. The problem with that, of course, is that if these recommendations are allowed to progress there will not be any community pharmacies for the inquiry to inquire into. It is a very sad reflection upon the Government, which has already destroyed our medical system. It has given us a two-tiered medical system under which the rich each year look after themselves but the poor suffer, and there are enormous waiting lists and poor service. The Government has already destroyed our medical system. Why is it now destroying our pharmaceutical benefits system via the destruction of the backbone of that system, our community pharmacies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten days ago I was privileged to represent the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the Adelaide opening of the Ancient Macedonia exhibition. This is a magnificent exhibition of ancient Macedonian art which was presented to this nation as a bicentennial gift by the people of Greece and funded by the Federal Government through the Australian Bicentennial Authority. The opening was attended by hundereds of Adelaide arts lovers and history buffs and also present were a number of members of parliament, both Federal and State and from all parties, who lent their support to the exhibition and shared in the general enthusiasm.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those present was my Federal colleague the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). It was appropriate that he should be there, not only for the obvious reason of his Greek background but because he was instrumental in bringing the exhibition to Adelaide. Originally Adelaide was not on the exhibition's itinerary and the people of Adelaide were going to be denied the pleasure of seeing these works. Because of the urgings of the honourable member for Calwell, among others, the exhibition did come to Adelaide and the people of that city are now coming in droves to view it. It was obvious from comments made by both Greeks and non-Greeks that they greatly appreciated the efforts of the honourable member for Calwell in bringing to Adelaide this exhibition, which depicts the ideas and aspirations of an ancient culture that helped form the foundations of modern culture throughout the world. I have to say, Mr Speaker, that with the congenial company and the delicious Greek food and wine, it was one of the most pleasant evenings I have ever spent. I do not think that the word `multiculturalism' was mentioned at all that night, but it did not need to be. This was multiculturalism at work naturally and unselfconsciously.

I have not mentioned the role of the honourable member for Calwell in this in order to promote the merits of that honourable member. His work in this Government, in this Parliament and in the Australian community speaks for itself. What has moved me to raise this subject is the unbelievably crass and offensive interjection which came from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) as the honourable member for Calwell was about to speak this afternoon in support of your nomination, Mr Speaker, for the position of Speaker of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. Under Standing Orders no member can attack another member without moving a specific motion. The honourable member is now drifting into a substantive attack on the honourable member for Adelaide. Her attention should be drawn to that particular standing order.
—The honourable member for Farrer is drawing a rather long bow.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I know that the honourable member is a fairly recent member to this House. I wonder whether she has informed the honourable member for Adelaide about--
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Warringah will resume his seat.
—The point which is the custom, as you would know, of this House.
—I warn the honourable member for Warringah.

—I remind honourable members that the honourable member for Adelaide did not take the courtesy of informing me when he did the same thing to me on several occasions during the adjournment debate in this House. In reference to the honourable member for Calwell the honourable member for Adelaide called out, `Have we got an interpreter?'. I will not comment on the intrinsic stupidity of that comment as it is obvious for all to see. The honourable member for Adelaide, of all people, was questioning the comprehensibility of one of the most eloquent and forceful speakers in this chamber. It was a gross offence directed at the honourable member for Calwell and towards other members of this House from a non-English speaking background, and to all Australians of non-English speaking backgrounds who are represented by the members of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Today was a broadcast day. No doubt some of the many people with non-English speaking backgrounds who live in the Federal electorate of Adelaide were listening and heard the Prime Minister, who was shocked by that interjection, make reference to it. They could not have realised that it was their member who was making that interjection. I trust that they will take that fact into account at the next election. I think it is particularly sad that in making that interjection the honourable member for Adelaide should have betrayed the other members of his Party who we know support a non-discriminatory multicultural policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) that has been a vital part of Australia's health care system, providing stability, reliability and safety. However, this scheme has been under constant attack by this Government and pharmacists are becoming desperate in an attempt to maintain viability to meet the demands of their clients effectively. This concern is genuine and warranted. Their frustrations have developed over a long period, as can be exampled by the addition of 53 frequently prescribed drugs to the authority only list and also by the extraordinary increases in the patient contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: We also know about the theoretical reduction of wholesalers' margins and the doubling of the maximum quantities of a considerable number of frequently prescribed items, with resultant loss of remuneration to pharmacists by way of professional fees. There was also the further reduction of remuneration of pharmacists by the reduction of the professional fee from 1 February last year. We have seen the demand for price reductions by manufacturers who are already supplying drugs for the Australian market at about half the price charged in comparable countries, to the extent that products of original research by these companies have been removed from the PBS since 1 April. The ability of the manufacturers of the cheap copies of these drugs to cope with the increased demand is questionable. In fact, many pharmacists have so far been unable to obtain stocks of certain necessary tablets.

In recent Budgets there have also been further changes to the remuneration to pharmacists, meaning a difference of up to 26 per cent. The effects of these changes to varying degrees will mean a loss of income for pharmacists with a consequent loss of taxation revenue. It will mean replacement of senior staff with lower paid junior staff or a reduction in the number of employees. It will bring about the closure of some pharmacies in small country towns, thus contributing significantly to the decline of such towns. Already in my electorate the pharmacy at Natimuk has closed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Balranald.

—In towns such as Balranald, in the electorate of the honourable member for Farrer, pharmacies have also closed. It will create a wastage problem which has already been recognised by Government Ministers, involving the expenditure of further funds on a campaign to try to prevent this wastage. The Government is enlisting the aid of the people whose incomes are being eroded by its mismanagement to help with publicity. It has already precipitated the costly preparation and distribution of pamphlets giving a biased account of the generic changes and bearing a photograph of an actor who pretends to be a doctor. Further wastage of public money on this campaign has been made on media advertising and on the mailing of a small communication in a gimmicky capsule which must have cost more than an envelope to produce and post.

SPEECH.PARA: I also express concern at the eligibility criteria of the essential pharmacy allowance (EPA) based solely on prescription volume and location. There seems to be an underlying assumption in the overall proposal that the decrease in mark-up will in part be compensated for by the benefits of future amalgamations and closures of pharmacies and that this rationalisation would benefit the remaining pharmacies by providing them with a greater share of the market. Such benefits would not flow to isolated rural pharmacies as distance precludes any chance of capitalising on this benefit. Surely location and isolation are sufficient criteria for the payment of an allowance to an isolated essential service, not the volume of work done, particularly if the service is limited by a low population base. Any inclusion of prescription volume, profitability or any other economic indicator denies the very purpose of recognising an essential service in its own right. The old isolated pharmacy allowance failed on this ground as the cut-off point was too low. It failed to acknowledge the effort, investment and risk of establishing and maintaining pharmacies in isolated areas of Australia. The financial viability of pharmacies in such communities will be seriously threatened by the changes proposed. These communities are under economic and social pressures and are undergoing acute structural readjustment.

The Government must restructure the EPA so that it recognises the essential nature of pharmacy services. I ask this Government to stop its confrontationist attitude to our professional groups who have good reason at times to challenge the veracity of policies and inappropriate change in attempts to patch up a chaotic health delivery service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with other members I was pleased that the statement on the environment that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) delivered on 20 August covered the areas of waste management and recycling. I was pleased that the statement proposed the establishment of a working group to develop standards for recycled paper, that it also proposed the removal of sales tax on certain products made from recycled paper, and that the Government will sponsor a study of recycling plastics litter. This is important action at the national level.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I want to refer to action on recycling at the local neighbourhood level. In this respect I wish to commend two Penrith women, Mrs Francine Tyson and Mrs Carol Byrnes, who, in their respective neighbourhoods, have coordinated door to door collections of recyclable goods. In this very worthy effort they have had the support of a local firm, General Recyclers of St Marys. Mrs Byrnes has provided data on her project, which operates in Fragar Road in Penrith. It originally began as a four-week trial of collections, but because of its success over those four weeks the effort is continuing. The project consists of door to door collections coinciding with the regular garbage collection night. Of 103 homes in her immediate area, 41 participated. The result over the month was that 1.557 tonnes of recyclable material was collected at a value of $117.86. This money was contributed to a local worthy cause. The Penrith City Council has expressed keen interest in each of these neighbourhood projects. Council officers are preparing a report on the possibility of extending the recycling effort within the city of Penrith. There are prospects at this stage for a greatly expanded effort within that city.

This evening I want to commend Mr Tyson and Mrs Byrnes. Their projects are worthy in two senses: first, they are demonstrations that recycling is a practical proposition; and, secondly, they show that ordinary citizens have the capacity to alter community behaviour and effect change. There is one particular statement that Mrs Byrnes has made in the attachment to her report which I think is worth repeating this evening. She said:

More and more people are becoming aware of the enormous problems our environment is facing and as individual householders and concerned parents they want to help ensure a brighter future for their children.
I congratulate both of these women for their initiative and enthusiasm and the highly practical contribution they are making.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When listening to the debate earlier tonight I heard the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) say that the Australian Medical Association seems to think that something is wrong with taking money from the Government. If ever there has been an example of where it is wrong to take money, it is the grubby way in which the Government has treated this country's pharmacists. I agree totally with that statement and we have seen the effect of that, of being tied to government. Other speakers in this adjournment debate have already detailed what has happened-that is, there has been a recommendation that pharmacists' remuneration be decreased by $1.05 per script.

SPEECH.PARA: What will be the effect of this? Today I received a phone call from a pharmacist just outside my electorate-someone I know very well. He is 30 years of age and is one of four partners in two pharmacies. He draws $32,000 a year from his pharmacy. If his wife works she gets paid the ordinary hourly rate of any other worker. He has no financial arrangements through the partnership other than what he draws in his salary. He works 48 hours a week and does not get loadings for his leave. He does not take lunch breaks or morning or afternoon tea breaks. Making allowance for the hours he works, on a 38-hour week he would get $22,600 a year, or $11.40 an hour. That is for a 30-year-old with a family who has done four years university training. Out of that $11.40 an hour he has to pay his expenses of buying into that pharmaceutical practice.

I do not deny that there is a problem with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS), but the problem is not where the Government is trying to hit it. On 12 April the Auditor-General's report was tabled in the Parliament. The report referred to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and made four specific points. It said, firstly, that the Department of Community Services and Health does not have enough detail to know whether overpayments are being made; secondly, that the Department is unable to confirm that people who receive free drugs are entitled to them; thirdly, that the Department does not record information about the people who receive the drugs; and, fourthly, that the Department is not able to verify automatically the entitlement of a patient to free or concessional medicine. What was the Government's response? It said that no overpayments were being made, although the Auditor-General had stated that even if they were being made no-one would be able to know.

As I see it, there are three specific problems with the PBS, none of which has been addressed by the Government. The first concerns the safety net. When the safety net was introduced into the Parliament the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) said that the arrangements were widely recognised as both cost efficient and directing resources to those most in need. The cost of those cost efficient resources was $143m last year, representing an increase of 25 per cent over the previous year. It went up because the resources are not being targeted. The safety net operates in such a way that a family of six living in Toorak or South Yarra can hit the safety net on its first overseas trip. For example, someone who has asthma and requires ventolin, which has a long shelf life, can get two years worth of ventolin in the first year and none the next year. By getting two years in one year he hits the safety net and comes in under the Government's scheme. That is why the costs have gone up. Secondly, significant capacity exists for fraud. That was stated in the Auditor-General's report and nothing has been done about it. Thirdly, there has been no determination that those who are getting drugs are entitled to them.

There is a problem, and the way to fix it is not by hitting this country's pharmacists in an attempt to reduce their income by 12 per cent last year and now 8 per cent this year. On top of that it is a decision which the Government cannot get away from because the decision was based on its own submission. This country's pharmacists deserve a better deal than they are getting from this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago in Question Time I raised the issue of renewable energy sources, particularly wind and solar energy, because at the time I was concerned that the State energy instrumentalities which are in the business of selling energy would hardly be those in the vanguard leading the push for conservation and for those renewable energy sources against traditional sources. I thought at the time that it was a bit like putting an arsonist in charge of a fire brigade.

SPEECH.PARA: A similar situation arises with road builders and the State Government's proposals for building roads. The issue in question in my electorate is the proposed Burswood Bridge and Northern City Bypass and comes out of a decision to relocate the Burswood Bridge in East Perth to a location near the Bunbury rail bridge and to connect that bridge with the Mitchell Freeway via roads through East Perth and Northbridge. The bypass road that would need to be developed within the proposal would cut dramatically through Northbridge and East Perth. While that proposal has been around for some time-it has been under consideration for many years and often postponed-it looks as though it may be gaining some credibility in the views of those who plan these things. However, many factors need to be considered. Indeed, we need to ask ourselves whether we really need more roads of this type.

Some of the new factors relate to a decision by the State Government to electrify and upgrade the railways and to establish a new line to the northern suburbs, because in view of the environmental considerations all sensible planners would know that public transport in this country needs to be developed dramatically. There is also a suggestion that the new road will relieve traffic flows in and around the city. While that may have a temporary effect, one needs only to look at the Mitchell Freeway in Western Australia. I feel very sorry for all those people who drive up to the northern suburbs on the weekend and buy a house up there because when weekdays come and they have to travel by car to the city they have to sit in long queues waiting for many minutes, and sometimes as much as an hour, to make the journey to the city. Whether it would relieve the traffic flows is conjecture.

There are also important environmental considerations. It is clear that fewer cars, less congestion, less emission gases and less energy usage are all environmentally sound objectives. Perhaps the push for more roads, better roads and more cars driving on them is something which we should be fighting against. Perhaps as important as anything to those who live in the inner city area is the impact that the roads will have on the inner city area. The area has changed and been regenerated over recent years. It has become a vibrant and exciting area. Many of the attractive buildings which had been allowed to run down have been restored. It is an area in which there is great potential for business and residential development. Cutting it in half with these proposed roads is a matter of a great concern to those who live and work in the area.

There are alternatives, and they include upgrading the railway system, which the Government has already said it will do. Consideration needs to be given to upgrading the railway bridge so that a city shuttle can be developed. Bypass roads are already under construction. Recently I travelled from Karrinyup to Perth Airport by Karrinyup Road, Morley Drive and the Tonkin Highway. When the northern perimeter highway is completed it will provide an excellent route around the city. Many people in my electorate are concerned about this development. The inner city Residents Action Group, the State planning people, many city planners and even Perth city councillors are concerned about it. We need to stand back from it and take a long term view, because by the time the decision is made to build it we may find that it is not necessary. It is clear that within the provisions of Federal funding-much of the money for this road system will come from Federal funding-it is possible for road funding to be diverted to urban transport; so there is no need for the State Government to miss out on some revenue or capital, but there may be other more important priorities for the money to be directed towards. This issue needs careful consideration and examination and the concerns of local residents must be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have not been monitoring the adjournment debate but I do understand that some comments have been made in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT). I think it is important tonight to make a few comments to put the whole issue into some context. First of all I think the point needs to be made that the Tribunal has been through an exhaustive process of considering well over 600 submissions and the Tribunal itself is an independent body. I think, within that, it needs to be also considered that the Government tried in April and May of this year to put a joint submission to the Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: That joint submission would have marked a level of agreement and understanding between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Government in a way that would have shown a cooperation and a desire to work together to form a submission that would hopefully go on to be taken into strong account in the Tribunal's deliberations. But that was not possible; the Government's offer was rejected and hindsight, I think, and history will show that that was a very generous offer. Today, now that the Tribunal has come down with a determination which is in effect law, life has been made difficult it would seem, if we are to believe what some pharmacists would say for them all. But the decision is the determination of the Tribunal.

As soon as the decision was released I contacted the Pharmacy Guild to offer to have discussions with it about some recommendations that were in the report. This is as distinct from the determinations that focus around the structure of the industry, such as the structure of retail pharmacy and the essential pharmacy allowance which was an initiative of the Government to take account of special circumstances, whether it be remote locality, small communities or different issues that makes a pharmacy in an urban environment essential. That could cover things like the need for a 24-hour service or the fact that, even in an urban environment because of the nature of the population and problems with transport, such a pharmacy is essential to that community.

The objective, of course, is to ensure that people get access to those pharmaceuticals and that the role of the pharmaceutical system and pharmacy as an intrinsically important part of the health care system is maintained. That offer was rejected. It concerns me that in the rejection of that offer therein lies the disaster for the community pharmacy. I would hope that in coming back to discussions with the Government the Pharmacy Guild and other interested elements of pharmacy would be able to develop, in conjunction with the Government, a constructive approach to some of these issues.

But there is another issue that is very important as far as I am concerned. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme is a much underrated scheme despite the fact that its cost was well over $1,000m last year and this year will be well over $1,200m. It is rising very rapidly for a variety of reasons: firstly, the general cost of some more expensive high tech drugs that are coming into the system as well as, of course, the number of people who are actually getting prescriptions. This is partly to do with our ageing population. So what we do have to is protect the scheme and ensure that it works. But it is not just simply a matter of selling drugs.

I think there is a very important role for pharmacists within the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and that role is to develop a much more proactive health care role for pharmaceuticals and the way in which they are used in our community. That is another issue that I hope to raise particularly with the pharmaceutical society which represents the ethical stream of pharmacy. But the problem is that we have to take into account that there is a lot of reaction in the community. It concerns me that a lot of the more moderate leaders and the more moderate people in the community in the past have been--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. Does the Minister wish to continue?
—Yes, I do, Mr Speaker.
—The Minister may continue.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Some of the more moderate pharmacists have been overshadowed in the past and I would hope, bearing in mind that the offer to the pharmacists back in May was rejected, that some of these more moderate elements may come to the party and show a different approach to the Government than has been there in the past. I say that sincerely because I do want to find a way to work with pharmacy, of course, in the development of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This is very importantly also in developing a broader role for community pharmacy.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we also have to consider that many things have been said, some of them simply not true and others simply misunderstandings and misinformation. As I said before, the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) is rising quite dramatically for those reasons, and the Government has tried on other occasions to find ways of dealing with that. Many pharmacists have put forward their ideas. But the sorts of things that have been put forward to offset the rising costs of the PBS such as altering safety net provisions and making pensioners pay-most of those suggestions coming from pharmacists, I might add-I do not think solve the basic issues. We are trying to develop a health care system, but not one that simply revolves around selling pills and the remuneration of pharmacists. I think that we need to pay a lot more attention to that issue than has been paid in the past.

It concerns me that there are a lot of people who are currently being over concerned and frightened by what some pharmacists are saying. I think that that is a concern because there are many people who are old and frail and who depend upon those pharmaceuticals for their health care and they are unnecessarily concerned. They would probably be more concerned if they realised that many of the people who are trying to frighten them at this stage are actually the people who are suggesting at the same time that the cost of drugs to them be increased. The reality is that many pharmacists have had posters in their windows that say, `Pensioners to pay-The Government's next step'.

There are a couple of pharmacists who have written to me. I think that if we went through the submissions to honourable members as well as to the PBRT we would see that that is exactly what a lot of pharmacists are saying. That is not the solution. The Tribunal has made its decision on the basis of costs and the fee in terms of dispensing is there. I make the offer to the Pharmacy Guild and to other national interested bodies to have discussions with the Government particularly around the recommendations and other elements that have been discussed. These are the structure of retail pharmacies in Australia; the guidelines for any essential pharmacy allowance; and very importantly the professional role of pharmacists. I want to make the point to people who are concerned that the Government considers the PBS is a most important element of the health care system and that Australians, no matter where they live, need not fear from any actions of this Government the loss of their entitlement or the loss of access to pharmaceuticals. The PBS protects very well in this country in a much underestimated way our frail aged and our sick, our chronically ill, those on low incomes and indeed all Australians. The availability of those best drugs at the best prices, on the basis that health is not determined by wealth, is fundamental to the PBS, and the Government will continue to have that to be the case.
